items.title:
keiyaA –
        hooke's law
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Bad blood. Depression. Snide landlords. And then there's all the fun in
        between. Written during a time of deep self-reflection,
        hooke's law follows keiyaA as she tears everything and everyone
        up only to emerge more invigorated than ever. Following her beloved
        debut album, these 19 tracks are a remarkable crossover between R&B,
        ambient and the kind of experimental music you might expect from
        genre-adverse producers like Klein and DJ Haram. Soulful and sexy,
        scornful and weird, the album charts an explosive period of emotional
        growth.

items.title:
DJ SWISHA –
        FIRST HAND SMOKE
items.label: Self-Released
items.description:
On his debut album, New York club king DJ SWISHA samples house, R&B and
        pop, folding his encyclopedic music knowledge into a pointedly North
        American package. Here, Baltimore club meets Jersey club, and footwork
        and juke beats rearrange the soulful molecules of R&B. There's nothing
        quite as earth shattering as "CLUB MEGAMIXXX" (RA's
        best track of 2023), but these are dance floor tools refined for the album format,
        meaning there's plenty of living-room listenability.

items.title:
DJ Babatr –
        Root Echoes
items.label: Hakuna Kalula
items.description:
Carefully selected from more than 700 archived works made between 2003
        and 2007, Root Echoes documents raptor house at its subversive
        peak. With each sweaty, speeding track, DJ Babatr redefines the genre
        with a watertight mission: amplifying Afro-Venezuelan voices.

items.title:
Various –
        Techno Kayō Vol. 1 - Japanese Techno Pop 1981 - 1989 (Compiled by
          Dubby & Antal)
items.label: Rush Hour
items.description:
Dubby, one of the curators of Japanese Techno Pop 1981 - 1989,
        recently told
        Magazine Sixty
        that techno pop has a "rather cheesy and slightly tacky image" in Japan.
        This compilation aims to correct that narrative—and how. Focusing on the genre's niche and experimental branches, it takes listeners from the cosmic funk of TPO and Linda's "Rock The Hour" to the leftfield sound collage of Kazuo Ohtani's "Last Battle."

items.title:
Blawan –
        SickElixir
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
These 14 brutal tracks judder from industrial hip-hop to syncopated
        sludge, redefining what a techno LP can be. But what really gives this
        record its otherworldly feel is Blawan's voice. Twisted into a monstrous
        rasp through layers of filters, it's the first thing we hear and it
        holds everything together from there on out.

items.title:
Carrier –
        Rhythm Immortal
items.label: Modern Love
items.description:
As a producer, Carrier specialises in white space. On
        Rhythm Immortal, the UK artist's use of percussion is the
        centrepiece, but the gaps he leaves in between the beats are the most
        compelling. Dub techno, ambient, industrial and jazz motifs unite in
        perfect harmony. Just listen to "Offshore," where slithering synths and
        hiccuping drums are tempered by saxophone and piano chords that gleam
        quietly like little spots of sun.

items.title:
Various –
        Rhythm 2 Revolt Solidarity Compilation
items.label: Hood Rave
items.description:
BAE BAE's Hood Rave party is one of Los Angeles' best. Why? Because of
        its outspoken commitment to liberation. The platform's first compilation
        splits proceeds between the
        Gaza Mutual Aid Solidarity Fund
        and
        NDLON's Immigrant Defense Fund, featuring songs that skitter between ambient, techno and East Coast
        club. Daniel Pineda's "Do Something" captures the sense of urgency
        underlining both politics and dance floors right now. Note the blaring
        siren, club breaks and a voice echoing, "Do something to stop the
        killing."

items.title:
Felicity J Lord –
        FJL
items.label: STROOM.TV
items.description:
Although technically released in late September, this album is catnip
        for fans of Voice Actor, Klein and Dean Blunt. A 26-track LP might seem
        like overkill these days, but FJL's vignettes are made for
        the ADD generation. These short songs loop familiar pop and R&B
        samples—cozy and familiar playgrounds from which emerge the most chaotic
        spoken word you'll hear on a record this year.

items.title:
Charmaine Lee
        –
        Tulpa
items.label: Kou Records
items.description:
This is the kind of record that will deeply satisfy experimental music
        enthusiasts who wait patiently every year for cutting-edge festivals
        like Unsound and Dripping. The New York artist's dark ambient
        soundscapes blanket intense, complex vocal processing that turns quick
        breaths, hums and tongue clicks into shuddering rhythms.

items.title:
CRRDR –
        LATINCORE LEGEND
items.label: LATINCORE
items.description:
Bogotá's CRRDR doesn't take his title of "Latincore legend" lightly. The genre he champions takes the speeding BPMs and
        blistering intensity of hardstyle, blending it with guaracha, reggaeton
        and dembow. Throughout his debut album, bachata meets Jersey club ("Te
        Gusta Mi Bachata"), Eurodance fuses with guaracha ("Oh Baby") and IDM
        synths glimmer over a reggaeton beat. Tapping vocalists from Ecuador,
        Puerto Rico, Colombia, Mexico, Venezuela and Chile, this a sublime
        representation of the Latincore movement.

items.title:
Dania –
        Listless
items.label: Somewhere Press
items.description:
Smoky drums, slushy guitar and a delicate voice that whispers through
        the darkness. Comprising seven tracks written after midnight, Dania's
        Listless takes the mystery of the witching hour and infuses it
        into this superb journey through shadow-filled trip-hop and fantastical
        ambient.

items.title:
Jasmín –
        Bite The Hand That Feeds You
items.label: Hessle Audio
items.description:
On her first fully fledged record—and Hessle Audio's 50th release—Jasmín
        continues to explore the label's techno-dubstep roots. This is a wicked
        batch of searing techno that snakes between Latin American rhythms,
        industrial and the deep blare of dubstep.

items.title:
Beatrice M. –
        Midnight Swim
items.label: Tectonic Recordings
items.description:
Another hit from an artist who can't stop making them. Rippling from
        dubstep to dub techno, Beatrice M. creates tracks with the quiet
        dynamism and depth of an ocean. It's so detailed that it's less of a
        soundscape than an entire new world of slippery bass and minuscule
        sounds, urging you to climb inside.

items.title:
Qemist –
        The New Juke Tape
items.label: Moveltraxx
items.description:
Juke and footwork were born in Chicago but they maintain a strong grip
        beyond the Midwest. Based out of Memphis, Tennessee, Qemist takes
        these genres and puts them into a blender, resulting in a high-BPM
        fusion of unwieldy, banging East Coast club, jungle and R&B.

items.title:
Full Circle –
        Beyond Knowhere
items.label: Good Morning Tapes
items.description:
Following a corrective Goa trance compilation aiming to give the
        Indian-born psychedelic dance sound its flowers, Parisian duo Full
        Circle continue their focus on the misunderstood genre on
        Beyond Knowhere. This is progressive house indebted to the
        psychedelia of Goa trance, featuring plenty of reverbed sitar and
        detailed acid. "Painting Noise" even has a trip-hop chug.

items.title:
De Grandi –
        Testa Dura
items.label: Tratratrax
items.description:
This full-throttle EP takes cues from dubstep, techno and club music,
        looping twisty, squelchy basslines and heaving drums to explosive
        effect. The record flies out the traps: the opening title track plows
        through a monstrous bassline and quick-fire drums. The remixes do the
        blistering tunes justice, with Call Super and Parris bringing a quirky,
        drum-forward house touch on their "Yeah But Still" version.

items.title:
Wata Igarashi, Polygonia –
        Cross Passage
items.label: Reclaim Your City
items.description:
Polygonia and Wata Igarashi approach hypnotic ecstasy from different
        angles: the former goes for blissed-out baubles; the latter embraces the
        growl of blazing arpeggios. On their latest collaborative EP, you can
        hear Polygonia's melodic brightness, while the grimey deepness sounds
        like the handiwork of Igarashi. Cross Passage is a gold mine for
        psychedelic techno enthusiasts.

items.title: NTS - 100% D'Angelo
items.description: Few artists have reshaped modern soul as profoundly as D'Angelo. Following his death in October, Shy One offers a heartfelt tribute tracing the arc of his genius, from the church-rooted warmth of Brown Sugar to the fractured funk of Black Messiah. Moving through hits, deep cuts and collaborations, this two-hour mix celebrates an artist who was forever chasing the divine through groove, analogue grit and a one-of-a-kind lyricism.

items.title: Closing Set at Sustain-Release 2025
items.description: As autumn settles across the northern hemisphere, a wave of festival recordings return to remind us of summer's glow. Among the standouts from this year's romp in Camp Kennybrook is a luminous two-hour journey from Mia Koden, RA's Breaking Through artist of 2024. Rooted in a deep love of Black diasporic music, she moves from dubstep to hip-hop, drifting from Commodo and Daweh Congo to Bahamadia and Minnie Riperton. According to one RA staffer on the dance floor, there were "tears everywhere" and a voice periodically yelling, "What the fuck, Mia?!"

items.title: Sugar Free at Selectors - Dekmantel 2025
items.description: A Sugar Free set lands differently. There's a sleazy allure to her take on techno, house and breakbeat, and her vinyl-only sets honour the tradition of the format while always sounding strikingly fresh. The Madrid-based DJ has a knack for uncanny blends: hypnotic grooves meet elastic basslines and trippy, late-night textures weave between deep techno, minimal and psychedelic trance. For her Dekmantel debut, she delivered what she does best: deep, headsy, timeless dance music.

items.title: NTS
items.description: Nine years since his last NTS Radio appearance, Henry Rollins returns with his trademark intensity intact. The LA icon—who has donned the role of band frontman, actor, essayist and more throughout his polymathic career—spends two hours digging through punk, hardcore and new wave treasures. It's an essential look into Rollin's unique, far-reaching collection.

items.title: Live At Dripping
items.description: Seattle's Succubass is a pillar of the US DIY underground, and for their Friday night set at Dripping, they turned The Barn into a fever dream of bass and distortion. Moving from Zvvra's tactile techno and the dub of Gil.Barte to the heady steppers of Commodo & Gantz, Succubass stitches together something raw, cinematic and deeply physical. Each drop makes it feel like the music was testing the limits of the small room.

items.title: MNMT 488
items.description: Listen to any set from Kia, Priori or Cousin and you'll likely hear the dubbed out productions of Mexican-Jamaican producer Andy Martin. Based in Guadalajara, he has become a quiet force in the global underground, uniting sci-fi techno with the rhythmic sensibilities of the Caribbean and Latin America. For Norway's Monument Festival, he delivers a transportive set that moves from the weightless dub pressure of Bukkha and Abstract Man into sleek, hypnotic techno from Oscar Mulero and Unbalance. Here's an hour of music laced with deep bass, subtle psychedelia and shimmering percussive detail.

items.title: IT.podcast.s14e07
items.description: Scott Zacharias has long been one of Detroit's best-kept secrets. His singular, offbeat taste has made his No Way Back sets the stuff of legend. This year's closing in the Outer Space Room was among his most personal yet—as Zacharias recounts in the description, his partner joined him on-stage at the end of the set to celebrate her pregnancy. Anchored by the spirit of Arthur Russell's "In The Light Of The Miracle," the set drifts through everything from cosmic dub and art-pop melancholia to ambient techno and ecstatic house over the course of five hours.

items.title: Making Time 2025
items.description: As cofounder of experimental label SLINK, K Wata has become one of New York's most exciting new producers, known for slinky micro-dubs and bass music that messes with perception. His set from this year's Making Time ∞ follows that same thread: psychedelic, dubstep-adjacent and full of pressure, threading tracks from Deadbeat, Wata Igarashi and Paleman into something that feels somehow both heavy and weightless. It's club music that breathes, flexes and rearranges the air around you.

items.title:
Malibu –
        Vanities
items.label: YEAR0001
items.description:
French electronic artist Malibu is known for her transcendental
        performances. When paired with white beams of light that circle her
        audience, her wordless live sets become deeply surreal.
        Vanities, her filmic debut album, aims to transport you to that
        otherworldly state. While it draws from the soothing chords and glittery
        instrumentation of New Age and baroque music, the silvery pop melodies
        steal the show. This is weighty, elegant ambient that should be listened
        to with a proper sub, so that its immersive waves of sound envelop you.

items.title:
Paul St. Hilaire
        –
        Paul St. Hilaire - w/ The Producers
items.label: Kynant Records
items.description:
Paul St. Hilaire (AKA Tikiman) has contributed his sweet, sinuous vocals
        to
        dub techno records
        since his early work with Basic Channel. His latest album is a treat to
        longtime fans, featuring a host of top-drawer producers. Shinichi
        Atobe's lurid house bubbles under Hilaire's reverbed vocals; Priori's
        zippy tech house meets his heavily distorted asides. This is
        collaborative experimentation at its finest.

items.title:
Acopia –
        Blush Response
items.label: Scenic Route
items.description:
Rich with shoegazey guitars, simmering electronica and frontwoman Kate
        Durman's most plaintive vocals to date,
        Blush Response luxuriates in rock elements that lingered in the
        margins of previous Acopia albums. The rawness of the instrumentation,
        peppered with tiny textural details, distinguishes this LP from the
        group's signature dream pop. By unpixelating their previous sound,
        Acopia reach the perfect balance between gut-wrenching drama and
        understated surrender.

items.title:
james K –
        Friend
items.label: AD 93
items.description:
On her hotly anticipated new LP, Friend, james K sets herself
        loose inside a carefully constructed assemblage of drum & bass, trip-hop
        and shoegaze, carving offbeat shapes from the contemporary resurgence of
        all three genres. The album is crisper, cleaner and more complex than
        any of her back catalogue, drawing from crystalline pop and rock while
        maintaining her characteristic enigma. Full of lush, expansive pads and
        skittering microbeats, these songs sound like half-remembered dreams.

items.title:
Sammy Virji
        –
        Same Day Cleaning
items.label: Polydor
items.description:
If you like Sammy Virji's radio-friendly, vocal-heavy UKG, you're going
        to love Same Day Cleaning. There's a real musicality to the
        album, which spans garage house, speed garage and more, with the warmth
        of acoustic instruments occasionally squeezed in. In tandem with some of
        the UK's most in-demand MCs and vocalists—Flowdan, Skepta, Issey
        Cross—Virji totally steps up, showcasing songwriting agility that
        explains the current hype and glut of sold-out shows.

items.title:
Joanne Robertson –
        Blurrr
items.label: AD 93
items.description:
Joanne Robertson is widely known for her vocal cameos on records by Dean
        Blunt and Elias Rønnenfelt. But her latest solo album,
        Blurrr, establishes her as an artist in her own right. Written in
        between painting sessions and caring for her toddler, the gorgeous LP
        features drumless guitar ballads alongside contributions from cellist
        Oliver Coates. Most arresting, though, are the moods she conveys.
        Achieving a compositional yin-yang, she somehow scores both the euphoria
        of depression and the grief of joy.

items.title:
Kelman Duran
        –
        Scorpio Falling
items.label: Scorpio Red
items.description:
Dembow experimentalist Kelman Duran makes shadowy music that conjures
        scenes of sodden tunnel paths at nightfall. Beneath his shrouded pads
        are distinctly Caribbean sounds, like dancehall and reggaeton.
        Scorpio Falling, his first album since 2021's
        Night In Tijuana, is a gritty journey through jazz, Memphis rap
        and dark ambient with spurts of spritely dembow breaking the meditative
        lull.

items.title:
Titanic –
        HAGEN
items.label: TAR / MM / UOH
items.description:
Titanic, the avant-garde project from producer and guitarist I. la
        Católica and cellist Mabe Fratti, returns with punkish elegance on
        HAGEN. The chords are brighter, Fratti's vocals more dynamic and
        the ascendent alternative pop swells to new heights. The instrumentation
        is raw and brash, and Fratti fits right into the mould, her voice
        bearing visceral emotions with fascinating lightness.

items.title:
Lucrecia Dalt
        –
        A Danger To Ourselves
items.label: RVNG Intl.
items.description:
The past few years have been intense for Lucrecia Dalt. The Colombian
        artist has experienced several seizures and an eight-second stop to her
        heart since her last album, ¡Ay!. She also fell head over heels
        in love. Her latest alt-pop album, A Danger To Ourselves, is
        full-on haunting, as she whispers through a hall of tip-toeing cello and
        guitar plucks. Tracks like "stelliformia" carry the immersive lyricism
        that you'll want to listen to alone in your room.
        A Danger To Ourselves bristles with the kind of eerie love poems
        that only Dalt could write.

items.title:
YS –
        Burn
items.label: ERF
items.description:
Breezing through laidback trip-hop, luminescent IDM and mellow vocal
        samples, Burn captures the understated cool that characterised
        trip-hop's golden era. On "Moth," Janet Jackson exhales through
        delightfully broken drums. "End" skews slightly darker, featuring a
        pitched-down vocal announcing that "the end of the world is coming" over
        sparkling beats. Wherever you end up on this masterpiece, you'll find a
        goldmine of sophisticated textures.

items.title:
LÉO LA NUIT
        –
        LE DON DES LARMES
items.label: Knekelhuis
items.description:
On LE DON DES LARMES, Franco-Algerian vocalist LÉO LA NUIT is
        accompanied by guitar, cello and the swirl of her own harmonised vocals.
        Written for her newborn child, these lilting folk lullabies are inspired
        by her Kabyle upbringing surrounded by Algerian chaabi. This is a
        strikingly beautiful portrait of her wispy vocals, which don't need much
        enhancement to make you feel like you've fallen into a world in which
        everything has suddenly and blissfully slowed down.

items.title:
Skepta,
        Fred again..
        –
        Skepta .. Fred
items.label: Epic Records
items.description:
Although Skepta still hasn't released his long-awaited album
        Knife and Fork, he's put out a flurry of extremely good singles
        and even stepped in to replace Deftones at Glastonbury with a much
        talked-about performance. For his next trick, he gives Fred again.., the
        super-producer of mixed reputation, some underground cred. The tracks
        are a welcome, sub-blowing display of 140 BPM club music, making even
        Fred again..'s most dedicated critics struggle to deny their fun.

items.title:
Maara –
        Revenge from the Penthouse EP
items.label: Ancient Records
items.description:
Maara is an exceptionally versatile producer. Her debut album,
        The Ancient Truth, reveled in slow, chuggy trip-hop, followed by a motley of cheeky,
        sapphic singles like "Mind The WAP" and, more recently, "I Wanna Scissor Ft. My Hot Ex." But really, her specialty is in building hypnotic, multi-textural
        worlds. Revenge from the Penthouse does this by barrelling
        through shades of progressive house, trance and breakbeats, keeping us
        completely locked across all five tracks.

items.title:
TYGAPAW –
        IMMIGRANT
items.label: Tresor
items.description:
The connection that Jamaican artist TYGAPAW has to their queerness and
        home country is written all across their raucous, politically charged
        techno. On their new EP, IMMIGRANT, they portray the immigrant
        experience in post-Trump America as oppressive and repetitive. "Black
        Trans Masculine Experience" gives the floor to Kings-Lee Rose, who
        discusses the societal isolation of Black trans masculine people before
        a flood of percussion fills the soundscape. In TYGAPAW's hands, deep
        feelings are meant to be released through the hips—you'll hear Jersey
        club, dancehall and techno rhythms skitter across "M32."

items.title:
JSPORT –
        No Turning Back
items.label: JSPORT WORLD
items.description:
From the moment you step off the ledge of its misty opener,
        No Turning Back situates you in banger after banger. The club
        rhythms are fierce and unrelenting, speeding through Jersey club beats,
        dancehall and red-hot R&B samples, all with the iciness of grime. The
        liner notes couldn't have said it better: "These aren't tracks you
        play—they're tracks that play you."

items.title:
Sam Goku –
        Explorations 02
items.label: Permanent Vacation
items.description:
Explorations 02 is a frolic through dub techno, fuzzy breakbeats
        and psychedelic deep house. The rhythms are effervescent and the drums
        occasionally go hard. But the one trait that stays consistent throughout
        is the record's glistening aura, made possible by birdsong, muted pads
        and chiming melodies. This EP is as close to nature as the dance floor.

items.title:
NEW YORK –
        Push
items.label: nypop
items.description:
Push sounds eerily familiar. In many ways, it's reminiscent of
        the late '00s, a time when artists like Chairlift, MGMT and Owl City
        ruled the radio with glitchy beats that seemed to blast euphoria into
        listeners' veins. NEW YORK builds on this template with a punkish
        haze, whispering into the mic as bleeps burst around them.

items.title:
Croft –
        Sanctuary / Shifty
items.label: Hang Tough
items.description:
On this two-track EP, Nottingham's Croft offers twisted, hypnotic tech
        house. Metallic dings penetrate the busy soundscape, as plasticky noises
        contort across shuffling broken beats. These are the kinds of trippy
        curveballs that force crowds to stick around.

items.title:
Jessy Lanza
        –
        "Slapped By My Life"
items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
Jessy Lanza wrote "Slapped By My Life" while her husband was undergoing cancer treatment and she longed to escape into an emotion that felt miles away from her everyday sadness. This track is
        pure optimism, carried by a sweet hook ("I miss you when you go") and
        colourful beats flying by at 158 BPM. It's one for the lovers.

items.title: Kia b2b Bitter Babe - Climate of Fear
items.description:
On paper, Kia b2b Bitter Babe shouldn't really work. The former loves
        supple shades of dub, IDM and techno, while the latter leans towards
        hazy, sensual and high-energy tunes. But this recording from Berlin
        party
        Climate of Fear
        proves otherwise. Across two hours of molten techno, trance and
        pan-Latin dance music, the duo showcase their command of complex
        rhythms—and why they're two of the best in the game right now.

items.title: Gavsborg - Kiosk Radio
items.description:
Jamaican dance music producers don't get the same recognition as their
        peers in Detroit, Chicago or Berlin. Hailing from East Kingston,
        Gavsborg carries the torch for this generation. The Berlin-based
        Equiknoxx founder has spent more than a decade reshaping dancehall with
        a leftfield sensibility—first breaking through with Busy Signal's
        charting single, "Step Out," before collaborating with everyone from
        reggae dub prince Addis Pablo to hip-hop icon Missy Elliott. On
        Brussels'
        Kiosk Radio,
        Gavsborg dropped a scorching mix of dancehall, jungle, zouk and dub,
        laced with the playful surrealism that defines his productions.

items.title: EMA - subglow/Live 6 per:sona
items.description:
There's a
        new generation
        of dubstep kids in town pushing the sound forward in thrilling
        directions.
        EMA, founder
        of the dub-focused Woozy label, is a key force in the movement alongside
        the likes of
        Beatrice M.
        and
        Mia Koden. For
        CCL's subglow series, she shared a recording from her
        kaleidoscopic set at French festival per:sona. Much like her wider work,
        it's adventurous and unpretentious, with two hours of tightly wound
        techno, modern steppers and snarling drum & bass grounded in spooky
        bassweight.

items.title: Short Span - Theory Therapy 82
items.description:
Across its eight-year run,
        Blowing Up The Workshop
        tested the limits of the online mix format, giving artists space to
        experiment and shaping a generation of adventurous listeners along the
        way. That same curatorial spirit runs through this new Theory Therapy
        session, which sees BUTW founder Matthew Kent digging into forgotten
        '00s CDs to piece together a loose set of dubbed-out ambient and
        downtempo house, with plenty of clicky percussion reminiscent of
        minimal's dominant era.

items.title: Keanu Nelson - NTS Radio (13th September 2025)
items.description:
Broadcasting from Papunya, one of Australia's most isolated communities,
        Luritja artist Keanu Nelson offers a rare window into the music and
        voices of the Northwestern territory. For his latest NTS Radio show, he
        drifts from ancestral chants and spectral atmospheres to desert rock and
        jazzy synth pop. The mix moves gracefully between the celebratory and
        the contemplative, its remarkable range making for a perfect morning
        listen.

items.title: Maito & Kuba'97 - Live at Klub Dramatik Festival
items.description:
Klub Dramatik
        is part of a new wave of Belgian parties putting the country's scene on
        the map. The first entry in its live series comes from two locals at the
        heart of the action: Maito and Kuba'97. Over three hours, they weave
        understated house, techno and psychedelia with the patience and flow
        that comes from years spent on the dance floor, beautifully capturing
        the exploratory spirit that has Belgium abuzz right now.

items.title: Spurge - Nowadays Nonstop: 06-21-25
items.description:
For his
        Nowadays
        debut during Juneteenth weekend, New York DJ and musician Spurge paid
        homage to his definition of Black sonic excellence. Featuring a range of
        mostly Black artists—K-HAND, Bad Brains, Princess Peggie, DJ Spanish
        Fly—it's a danceable, thought-provoking showcase of Black artistry
        across noise, ambient techno and peak-time club.

items.title: Camille Mandoki - Series 029
items.description:
Mexico City vocalist Camille Mandoki—who features on
        Lucrecia Dalt's
        new album—makes powerful sound art. Her gauzy compositions and choral
        voice carry serious emotional weight, shaking listeners to their core.
        Her contribution to local mix series Lapi + Filia is just as
        poignant, featuring delicate jazz, ambient and folk that evoke
        introspection and fulfillment.

items.title:
DJ K –
        Radio Libertadora !
items.label: Nyege Nyege Tapes
items.description:
Radio Libertadora ! takes bruxaria, a maniacal strain of
        Brazilian baile funk, and imbues it with the sound of political
        discordance. Deteriorating synth lines buzz like digital waste and
        sirens bleat endlessly towards societal collapse. The album plays with
        genres such as techno, house and '00s hip-hop to bring its messages
        home. Like the directors of the most exhilarating action films, DJ K
        specialises in organised chaos. Resilience has rarely sounded so
        electrifying.

items.title:
Blood Orange –
        Essex Honey
items.label: RCA
items.description:
More than being an excellent producer, Dev Hynes, AKA Blood Orange, is a
        master of various styles. He's produced experimental R&B with Solange,
        composed for films and worked with the London Symphony Orchestra. His
        first album in six years brings his experimental edge to the fore, with
        a hefty features list including Mabe Fratti, Caroline Polachek and
        Tirzah. These are gorgeously gentle and stripped-back guitar- and
        piano-led pieces.

items.title:
Valesuchi
        –
        Futuro Cercano
items.label: Discos Nutabe
items.description:
On Futuro Cercano, Valesuchi's newfound love of higher BPMs is on
        full display, featuring not just techno and electro but also dubstep
        ("L.O.S."). Just about every synthline is in a minor key and evokes the
        imagery of a Halloween house of mirrors. Still, there are plenty of
        beautiful moments of elation. Just wait for when trance chords turn
        "Regreso" into a sunset anthem.

items.title:
Nourished By Time
        –
        The Passionate Ones
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Nourished By Time's second album, The Passionate Ones, ponders
        love, loneliness and late-stage capitalism over an impeccable blend of
        electro funk and breezy indie pop. Its soulful sound, driven by cruising
        guitars and euphoric synths, buffs up his candid lyrics, making his
        verses (which channel the extreme honesty of 2013-era Tyler, the
        Creator) all the more relatable. This is music for when you're down and
        out, and you just need a good tune to get you through the day.

items.title:
Amaarae –
        Black Star
items.label: Interscope Records
items.description:
Featuring cameos from Black luminaries like PinkPantheress, Naomi
        Campbell and Bree Runway, Black Star embraces the Black
        electronic music that formed Amaarae's youth. These sounds wafted from
        the streets to her ears in Accra at the age of six, then at eight in
        Atlanta, then New Jersey when she was 11. At its best,
        Black Star shows an artist amplifying Afrodiasporic club
        traditions with modern verve, unlocking a new wave of Black pop stardom
        along the way.

items.title:
Kaytranada
        –
        AIN'T NO DAMN WAY!
items.label: RCA
items.description:
Kaytranada's surprise new album, AIN'T NO DAMN WAY!, is the
        star's finest since 99.9%. It bottles the nonchalant sex appeal
        and restrained production of his 2016 debut, then distills it, cutting
        out the featured vocalists and paring down the runtime. The result: a
        dextrous blend of soul, R&B and old-school hip-hop—styles that he's only
        previously explored with singers or rappers—packaged in his signature
        dance MO.

items.title:
Stone –
        Dream Curtain Eternally Gentle
items.label: 3XL
items.description:
Dream Curtain Eternally Gentle adds chugging, perfectly sedate
        trip-hop beats to Stone's already blissfully organic ambient and
        squiggly IDM. "Tiny" wraps emotion into reverbed guitar and vocal blips.
        "Pixie" is light and pensive, with synth work and chimes that land like
        gentle pebbles against misty lily pads. This is one for overcast
        mornings and late-night drives.

items.title:
Kloke –
        Lucidity
items.label: Mindgames
items.description:
On Lucidity, Kloke delivers another excellent survey of modern
        jungle and drum & bass. Take "Invisible City," which transitions from
        soaring pads to angry breaks. The album's musicality, shown on the
        sweet, soulful melodies of "Spaces" and "The Man Who Began To Suspect He
        Was Made Of Glass," is balanced by some of the nastiest basslines you've
        ever heard.

items.title:
Oli XL
        –
        Lick The Lens / Pt.1
items.label: Warp
items.description:
Six years after the release of his cherished debut album,
        Rogue Intruder, Soul Enhancer, Oli XL returns with another LP highlighting his glitched-out
        soundscapes and delightful, pitched-up vocals. This time he brings an
        all-star roster of guests, including james K, Chanel Beads and Ecco2k,
        making for a sound that leans closely to glitch pop.

items.title:
Susumu Yokota
        –
        Skintone Edition Volume 1
items.label: Lo Recordings
items.description:
Seven albums tracing the genre-expansive genius of Japanese ambient
        legend Susumu Yokota. Get lost in the delicate triumph written into the
        skipping piano on "Morino Gakudan," groove to the loose, hand
        drum-driven house of "Pegasus Man" and lollygag to the guitar-laced
        ambient of "23 Degrees Dream."

items.title:
Various Artists –
        kwia 4eva
items.label: kwia
items.description:
In Kiana Mickles'
        nightlife column, Office
        Hours, Berlin ambient bar kwia was described as "a soft playground made
        for sensitive people." Now that the venue is facing the threat of
        closure, kwia 4ever is a sonic time capsule of the original soft
        club. Regular DJs Nick León, River Moon and mobilegirl contribute a
        relaxing medley of ambient, glitch and guitar music. Perfect for sinking
        into a plush couch.

items.title:
Guedra Guedra
        –
        MUTANT
items.label: Smugglers Way
items.description:
Guedra Guedra brings together an impressive assortment of Pan-African
        influences on MUTANT. Asymmetrical beats meet traditional
        instruments; bass music meets ancient rhythms. It's the kind of
        memorable—and extremely danceable—album that pushes the boundaries of
        every genre it touches.

items.title:
Skee Mask –
        E
items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Skee Mask impresses again
        on his surprise album, E. Intricate breakbeat science plays out
        on tracks like "Untitled 1017" and "501v2." Elsewhere, techno is
        rough-edged and deconstructed, with distorted beats lumbering forward
        like they're being pulled downhill.

items.title:
Florian TM Zeisig
        –
        A New Life
items.label: STROOM
items.description:
Awe-inspiring ambient that will instantly transport you to every
        peaceful moment you've experienced. Waves lap up against soaring
        saxophone on "Eternal Shore," the delicate layers of harmonies on "Die
        Große Natur" recall the jubilation of the first day of spring, and on
        "Life's A Spiral," harp trickles down a celestial soundscape like rays
        of sunlight.

items.title:
keiyaA –
        "Stupid Prizes"
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Play stupid games, win stupid prizes. keiyaA returns with her first song
        since the release of her cherished 2020 debut album,
        Forever, Ya Girl. This sneak peek at new music brings a haunting
        aura to her typically soulful R&B, and gives us a lot to look forward to
        in this new era.

items.title:
Paurro –
        Sea Bunny
items.label: aanjel
items.description:
Paurro's first EP on aanjel, her label with Valeriana, is a psychedelic
        journey through submerged basslines and progressive house squiggles.
        Listen closely as subtle layers of new sounds are introduced—a flash of
        a breakbeat, a trickle of a hand drum—and spritely vocals ooze out of
        the spaces between each curvilinear rhythm.

items.title:
JiaLing –
        WUPS!
items.label: Sorry Records
items.description:
JiaLing adds a little bit of everything to the Baltimore club formula:
        across these four tracks, there are nods to ballroom, diva house,
        dubstep and electro. The EP is bouncy, filled with cartoonish sound FX
        that channel the silly energy conveyed through a title like WUPS!

items.title:
Tracey –
        Sleazy
items.label: AD 93
items.description:
With 8-bit synths and scrappy lyrics, "Sleazy" has the deranged feel of
        an Adult Swim theme tune and the innovation of a SOPHIE song. Glitch by
        glitch, the mysterious duo paint a scandalous scene. Even if you're not
        quite sure what's going on, you'll be at the edge of your seat—and
        loving it.

items.title:
Sofia Kourtesis
        –
        Volver
items.label: Ninja Tune
items.description:
Volver doubles down on Sofia Kourtesis's strengths. Recorded
        while caring for her late mother in Peru and working with queer and
        trans advocates, the EP offers many iterations of her joyful noise.
        "Canela Pura" has a bit of the old French Touch ooh la la filter that
        she often threads into her DJ sets, along with a skippy bassline and the
        backspin goofball energy of Eris Drew. Much of these tracks sound like a
        body in pleasure: on the ecstatic piano house of "Nitzan and Aminaa,"
        percussion tickles the ears like a welcome hand on your back.

items.title: Unsound Podcast 107: DJ E / Chuquimamani-Condori
items.description:
First tested at the opening of last year's Unsound in Kraków, this mix
        captures the singular, hyper-charged style that has made
        Chuquimamani-Condori (AKA DJ E) one of electronic music's most
        unpredictable forces. It feels like a dispatch from an oasis far removed
        from the parameters of experimental music as we know it. Across 48
        minutes, Andean folk, cumbia and country music are bent and spliced into
        a delirious wall of sound, stitched together with the Bolivian-American
        artist's signature soundboard FX.

items.title: naffcast010 ⦾ Jasmín 𐔌՞. .՞𐦯 ୭ ˚. ᵎᵎ
items.description:
For the tenth edition of NAFF's mix series, former De School resident
        Jasmín swaps her usual broken bass sound for minimal house and techno.
        Recorded during a summer heatwave, the set layers faint voices,
        distorted drums and low-end pressure into a feverish atmosphere.
        Spanning long-time favourites (DJ Koze, Ricardo Villalobos) and recent
        digital finds, she leans into long, subtle blends, tapping into the
        ongoing resurgence of minimal's hypnotic pull.

items.title: Animix One Hundred & Seventy Nine: Agonis
items.description:
Basel's amenthia recordings may have carved out a niche with its
        leftfield, slow-burning techno, but label cofounder Agonis shows the
        vibes needn't be austere. Here, the Swiss DJ and producer delivers 66
        minutes of colour and warmth for Kia's beloved
        Animalia series. Groovy, trippy selections are threaded with
        vocals and trance flourishes. It's a reminder that hypnotic techno can
        move with both depth and vibrancy, balancing ritual intensity with
        playful, body-driven momentum.

items.title: ITPS119 LIMITED NETWORK
items.description:
Max Watts is elusive. The Detroit-based artist once wiped his entire
        discography from the internet, which only made the buzz around him grow
        louder. Known for peak-time tracks and vinyl turntablism that recall
        legends like Claude Young, he's quietly become one of techno's most
        compelling underground voices. For the latest Ilian Tape Podcast,
        he dives into aquatic shades of techno and electro, teasing the upcoming
        release on his label, Limited Network.

items.title: GQOM MIX TAPES E67 | AUGUST 2025 w/ MAMTHUG
items.description:
"Archiving gqom, one mix at a time," reads the tagline for Oroko Radio
        resident Mamthug's GQOM MIX TAPES series. Emerging from Durban's
        townships in the early 2010s, gqom quickly became one of South Africa's
        most influential party genres, defined by heavy bass, stripped-back
        percussion and a brooding intensity. On this episode, Mamthug—usually
        drawn to jazzy breakbeats—leans fully into gqom's vast spectrum, moving
        from sensual cuts to sub-rattling bangers, highlighting both the
        intimacy and force of a genre that remains as vital as ever.

items.title: Transmissions 001: Sunju Hargun
items.description:
Transmissions, the excellent London party spotlighting psychedelic club
        music, books hypnotic techno experimentalists such as DJ Nobu, Polygonia
        and Donato Dozzy. For those unable to attend the raves IRL, the crew has
        started a new mix series, launching with Bangkok-based DJ and label
        owner Sunju Hargun. A recording from FOLD's cosier second space, the
        Steam Room, the session opens with ceremonial chants. Vocals twirl
        around body-rattling bass and eerie synth lines, eventually giving way
        to two hours of Hargun's unique take on trippy techno.

items.title: In Focus: DJ Medhi (mixed by Antonine Scali)
items.description:
NTS Radio's latest In Focus celebrates DJ Mehdi, a
        hip-hop-kid-turned-house-DJ who defined a generation of Paris nightlife
        in the early 2000s. Raised on the outskirts of the French capital by
        Tunisian parents, he began producing mixtapes and beats inspired by J
        Dilla, before emerging as an unlikely icon of the Paris party scene. His
        radiant selections helped stitch together disparate worlds, from Daft
        Punk and Justice to MC Solaar. This hour-long mix captures that alchemy:
        rugged, sample-heavy productions for 113, Rohff and Mafia K'1 Fry sit
        alongside glossy, synth-driven anthems like "Pocket Piano," culminating
        in the euphoric climax of Thomas Bangalter's edit of "Signatune."

items.title: Strøm Mixx 044 - Mbizo
items.description:
Mbizo spins an hour of his own productions for Strøm Festival,
        Copenhagen's long-running celebration of electronic music and sound
        culture. While the Danish city has in recent years become known for
        high-BPM techno, Mbizo carves out a different path, grounding his set in
        old-school steppers, digi-dub and meaty dubstep (listen out for the
        cheeky JME edit). It's a refreshing counterpoint—and a seriously
        impressive showcase of Mbizo's studio skills.

items.title:
DJ Haram –
        Beside Myself
items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
Beside Myself is a masterfully precise debut album that revels in
        its harshness: glowering verses, wailing strings, field recordings of a
        bustling New York (footsteps, incoming trains, old apartment buzzers)
        that crackle and simmer. The LP feels like a whirlwind night out, with
        influences running the gamut from
        Tennessee rap
        to
        Kim Gordon. It
        refuses to settle, sweeping listeners up into its galvanising clamour.

items.title:
Qur'an Shaheed
        –
        Pulse
items.label: Leaving Records
items.description:
Both building on and breaking down the refined neo soul of her 2020 EP,
        Process, Qur'an Shaheed's first full-length flourishes in the
        space between craftsmanship and creativity, bucking structure for
        improvisational freedom. Her blend of pitch-shifted, syncopated
        spoken-word, fluttering hums and lo-fi glitch FX evokes the boundless
        jazz fusions of artists like duendita and keiyaA. Shaheed's warm timbre
        is versatile enough to leap from the latter's trademark looped harmonies
        to Outkast-esque skits.

items.title:
Various (Tectonic) –
        Tectonic Sound
items.label: Tectonic Recordings
items.description:
Tectonic's latest compilation represents a compelling snapshot of where
        dubstep and dubstep-adjacent music stand right now. There's shuffly,
        soulful broken beat (2562's "Overcome"), weighty half-step skankers
        (J.Sparrow's "Genesys") and bassy techno tools (Pinch & Neffa-T's "This
        Is This Isn't"). Listening to
        Tectonic Sound from start to finish feels like microdosing the
        label's entire back catalogue.

items.title:
Hieroglyphic Being
        –
        The Sound Of Something Ending
items.label: Mathematic Recordings
items.description:
In Jamal Moss's expression as Hieroglyphic Being, there are no bum notes
        or wrong ideas. On The Sound Of Something Ending, gritty blips
        and elysian arpeggios constitute the album's beating heart. Through both
        analogue and digital manipulation, he uses a staggering array of synth
        textures to convey everything from shivering anxiety to spiritual
        ecstasy.

items.title:
Slikback –
        Attrition
items.label: Planet Mu
items.description:
Attrition, Slikback's first album on Planet Mu, explores themes
        of transition and reflection. Written during a relocation to Poland and
        the expectant arrival of the musician's first child, it's his most
        mature and realised work to date. The drums strike first. Violent and
        chaotic, his mutant programming often feels like he's flipping through a
        rolodex of trap and hard dance sub-genres at an accelerating pace. And
        yet, the LP's softer moments are among its most compelling.

items.title:
Stars of the Lid
        –
        Music for Nitrous Oxide
items.label: Artificial Pinearch Manufacturing
items.description:
Stars of the Lid's 1995 debut album is regarded as a classic within the
        ambient and drone world for a reason. The record is dense enough to wrap
        around and colour an environment, but never too imposing. This
        30th-anniversary reissue highlights the pioneering drone duo's staying
        power. The smudged guitar flickers on "Down" gently speak to the current
        moment. In the era of Spotify's anodyne functionality playlists, the
        majesty of a slowly undulating drone piece like "Goodnight" feels like a
        brilliantly comical riposte to the idea of easy-listening music. But
        those subtle challenges have guided Stars of the Lid from the beginning.

items.title:
Madonna –
        Veronica Electronica
items.label: Warner Records
items.description:
It makes sense that Madonna is still exploring the world she created
        with 1998's Ray of Light. The rest of us are, too. This year
        alone has seen pop divas like FKA twigs and Addison Rae summon its
        spirit both
        reverentially
        and
        referentially. The LP's long-awaited remix album, Veronica Electronica, is
        pleasant nostalgia for the golden era of late-'90s dance music, a
        compact insight into who Madonna was listening to, inspired by and
        collaborating with when she wrote her magnum opus.

items.title:
rRoxymore
        –
        Juggling Dualities
items.label: !K7 Records
items.description:
Inspired by New Age music and the spacey, mind-expanding work of Carl
        Craig in the late '90s, rRoxymore imbues her latest album with driving
        hooks and gorgeous swathes of pads. From the glittering techno of
        "Moodified" to the alien chug of "Solace," this is an album that will
        guide you through trippy visions across all tempos.

items.title:
Two Shell
        –
        IIcons
items.label: Young
items.description:
On IIcons, anonymous trickster duo Two Shell find a happy medium
        between their newer
        hyperpop-influenced sound and the UK bass that defined their early career as
        producers on Livity Sound. The album (likely named in reference to their
        2022 EP, Icons) swings from poles with an almost comical
        severity. "beeep" sounds straight out of the London underground,
        lurching forward with skippy drum programming and blustering sub-bass,
        while "w a k e u p" pulls from Eurodance, all chintzy synths and zooming
        melodies.

items.title:
Sugar Free
        –
        Disociando
items.label: Icelab
items.description:
Sugar Free's debut EP mirrors her provocative DJing style. Borrowing
        from prog house, electro-soldered techno and '80s sleaze,
        Disociando is one of the year's best club 12-inches. Its darkness
        is most palpable on the B-side. "Vale" starts with skippy, Perlon-style
        drum programming, only to morph into the claustrophobic techno that's
        become synonymous with the
        Montevideo scene. "Mentalizate" merges DJ Nobu's psychedelia with contemporary minimal.
        It feels weightless, as if you've entered a gravity-free chamber.

items.title:
Danny L Harle,
        PinkPantheress
        –
        Starlight
items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
Danny L Harle's 2021 Harlecore LP was a post-pandemic work that
        fed off internet rave as much as happy hardcore and early '00s
        Eurodance. He brought it to life with alter ego MC Boing, whose
        high-pitched voice bore a striking resemblance to the CGI-animated Crazy
        Frog. He's since worked with real-life artists such as Caroline
        Polachek, Oklou and now PinkPantheress. Opening with ominous choral
        pads, "Starlight" makes use of PinkPantheress's saccharine, Auto-Tuned
        vocals, creating a misty atmosphere amid the relentless energy.

items.title:
FKA twigs
        –
        Perfectly
items.label: Young
items.description:
A
        Eusexua
        deluxe LP appears to be on the way. It doesn't take long to deduce that
        the pop auteur's new single, "Perfectly," is an alternate version of
        album cut "Perfect Stranger." The charging chords of the original are
        underpinned by a torrent of techno kick drums, turning the garage pop
        song into the kind of track that would fill a concrete dance floor at
        your favourite rave.

items.title:
Siavash Amini –
        Caligo
items.label: Room 40
items.description:
Anchored by spectral snippets of two of the earliest piano recordings in
        Iran's history, Caligo is a reconfiguring of a historical
        document that shifts between dark ambient and noise, burying deep into
        the brain. Water droplets flood piano plinks ("Spiraling P.M.") and the
        sound of tape unraveling hisses through clattering instruments ("Sanguis
        Stilla"). Moments of quiet are eventually uprooted, unveiling the chaos
        lurking underneath.

items.title:
Command D,
        Zara –
        Gravity Reset
items.label: Butter Sessions
items.description:
Command D makes dub techno with tight, pointillist drum programming that
        adds a distinct sharpness to his sludgy, sub bass-driven atmospheres.
        Zara makes tactile IDM with intricate sound design you can get lost in.
        Together, the two producers combine the heaviness of Command D's work
        with the squirming needlepoint embellishments of Zara's catalogue.

items.title:
tiro! –
        Mountain Loop // Forest Loop EP
items.label: Self-Released
items.description:
tiro! was gifted with a fascinating ear for loops. His music is bubbly
        and life-affirming, carrying the laid-back groove of second-generation
        Chicago house even though he's based on the other side of the world in
        Johannesburg. "Went on a hike and got inspired," he shares on the
        two-track EP's liner notes. The lush, repetitive churn of life
        experienced on those nature walks are all over this record, from the
        sunny synths on "Forest Loop" to the melody on "Mountain Loop," which
        flies between flangered chords and woody percussion.

items.title:
Patrick Holland
        –
        In Memory
items.label: Verdicchio Music Publishing
items.description:
Patrick Holland's recent records have been about slowing down; cruising
        house tracks that pack more melody than kick. This EP's opener, "Fast
        Forward," marks a noticeable shift in energy level, with a glitchy drum
        pattern and revved-up acidline. "Classless Act" tempers the A-side's
        peak-time palette, grooving to a restful pace with dubby pads and chirpy
        house drums.

items.title:
Pangaea –
        Manía / Neuromance
items.label: Hessle Audio
items.description:
Is there a vocal Pangaea can't work with? The Hessle Audio cofounder
        makes dance floor destroyers with undeniable roots in UK bass, and
        "Manía" is another banger on the docket, making use of Jazz Alonzo's
        seductive Spanish vocals over high-octane grooves. "Neuromance," pitched
        at 155 PM, features a storming synth pop melody that's enough to excite
        even the moodiest clubber. The cherry on top? Chipmunk vocals.

items.title:
Jubilee –
        FreaQE
items.label: Magic City
items.description:
On FreaQE, Jubilee plays a game: how many genres can you fit into
        a three-track EP? "Ford Focus" merges Miami bass's 808s, the slithery
        synth lines of UK bass and East Coast club amen breaks. The title track
        bounces with the fervour of Jersey club, while acid house synths and
        dubstep subs create a ferocious energy. And "FreaQE (NIGELTHREETIMES'
        HORNY OPERATOR REMIX)" is the drum & bass edit DJs will want to keep in
        their back pocket.

items.title: 8 Deck Technical Mix
items.description:
Neffa-T's 8 Deck Technical Mix is a stunning showcase of the
        continued potential of mixing records. Never one to rest on his laurels,
        the CDJ wizard's latest filmed session is 80 minutes of jaw-dropping
        skill. More than just a numbers stunt, his use of eight decks and two
        mixers allows for razor-sharp cuts and the spontaneous recomposition of
        tracks in real time, blurring the line between DJing and live
        performance. Almost constantly moving, it's as transfixing to watch as
        it is to listen to. Much like Jeff Mills' seminal
        Exhibitionist
        series, this is a vulnerable, high-wire act of solo mastery that will be
        talked about for years. Just remember the popcorn.

items.title: Heaven is in You
items.description:
ADAB is one of the
        US's best (and most underappreciated) DJs. On the latest instalment of
        their NTS Radio residency, the Philadelphia-based artist explores some
        of their favourite contemporary amapiano cuts from the likes of
        Thebelebe, Lowbass Djy, Jazza MusiQ and Bukzin Keyz. Focusing on darker,
        more innovative strains, it's a compelling exhibition of the South
        African genre today.

items.title: Hessle Audio - 30 June 2025
items.description:
"It's experimental music that people have to move to." So
        said
        Ben UFO back in 2016 when reflecting on A Made Up Sound's unique appeal.
        For a decade, the musician's catalogue was home to a wild alchemy of
        sounds—take "Afterhours," a lurching, 12-minute hybrid of dubstep and
        Detroit techno—that inspired total awe in his contemporaries. Though the
        Dutch producer has kept a low profile in recent years, his latest
        project, ex_libris, proves that his guiding ethos of innovation has only
        deepened. His two-hour Hessle Audio takeover, which explores a range of
        personal favourites and early influences (Mary J. Blige, Krust), is a
        markedly intimate offering from an artist who's long thrived on bending
        boundaries in every direction.

items.title: NTS Iran Special
items.description:
On her recent NTS Radio show, Maral stitches together an hour of Iranian
        folk and classical music, the ghostly ambient washes of Grouper and her
        own blown-out electronics. In her own words, the
         Iran Special mix taps "into the liminal feelings of being in the
        diaspora—a blend of sadness, anger, fear and nostalgia. A cathartic mix
        for anyone in the world." An essential and absorbing listen.

items.title: The Lot Radio 06-27-2025
items.description:
Last month, after travelling stateside on a ship, Nono Gigsta made a
        stunning debut at
        Dripping. Afterwards, she
        headed to The Lot Radio to prove why she's got the widest range in the
        game. Her ability to infuse eccentric elements into dance music is
        particularly unique—breaky techno suddenly morphs into ghostly drone;
        sombre organ notes give way to zany synth patterns. In her hands,
        anything and everything is possible.

items.title: Good Work – 12 July 2025
items.description:
Loidis has an uncanny ear for deep tech house gems, the kind with
        slippery grooves, punchy synths and foggy dub rhythms. These
        delightfully minimal cuts form the bulk of this four-hour set at
        Brooklyn's Good Work. The Kansas native, AKA Huerco S., has plenty to
        show off, never lingering on one strain of tech house for too long. His
        style goes way beyond traditional mnml (though there's plenty of that in
        here too), incorporating raw funk, slinky drums and weirdo house to
        devastating effect.

items.title: Timeless Series #52
items.description:
This ambient and downtempo session is a mental massage for knotty
        thoughts. Ethereal pads, lush soundscapes and nature noises (frog
        ribbits, the plink of water droplets) seem to capture a time-lapse of a
        tropical ecosystem. Over the rhythmic chug of distorted synth lines,
        hissing melodies and barely there vocal samples, Moopie soundtracks a
        rainforest in transition, taking listeners across the seasons. It's an
        hour of pure, contemplative bliss—and a critical ear cleanse.

items.title: Truancy Volume 353
items.description:
In the hands of james K, music becomes emotional architecture. Layering
        melancholy, surrender and longing alongside murkier feelings such as
        anxiety, the New York-based artist builds sets like an urban planner of
        the heart. This 74-minute trek across mediative downtempo, drum & bass
        and sample-based experimentalism finds through lines between artists on
        the opposite sides of the dance music spectrum, from the delicate piano
        notes of Tristan Arp to Marco Shuttle's quiet percussion. It ends on a
        bittersweet note with the IDM pop of Cybermission's "Deep Hard," which
        james K
        described
        as her "current favourite feeling" because "it's fun, beautiful and
        real."

items.title:
Black Sites –
        R4
items.label: Tresor
items.description:
On R4, Helena Hauff and F#X recapture their legendary live-wire
        energy for the breeziest club record in Hauff's discography, and the
        danciest in F#X's. The album—the duo's first release in 11
        years—provides plenty of opportunities for them to break out, like the
        crushingly heavy electro of "II," with its Nine Inch Nails-style
        distorted kick drums and curdled synths. "707," all jagged edges and
        jutting angles, sounds like they tried to make the ugliest acid track
        possible.

items.title:
Introspekt
        –
        Moving the Center
items.label: Tempa
items.description:
For her debut album on the storied dubstep label Tempa, Introspekt
        commits to actualising dubstep's sensual potential by incorporating
        elements of house, Detroit techno, UK garage and East Coast club. Her
        convergence of influences, from soulful shuffle to garage-grime, evokes
        Big Apple Records and early FWD>> parties, but without becoming bogged
        down in bland revivalism. Just listen to the thick, rolling riffs of
        wobble bass on "Make Me Dance" and "Respect," which channel the
        broodiness of Plastician's early tunes.

items.title:
Lyra Pramuk
        –
        Hymnal
items.label: 7K!
items.description:
While working on her third album, Hymnal, Lyra Pramuk was moved
        by the beauty of the nature that surrounded her. Collaborating with a
        string quartet for the first time, she included flute, double bass and
        raw, improvised vocal harmonies that contrast with sleek electronic
        production. The resulting LP is multitudinal: tactile and knotty yet
        fluid and trance-like, offering all the forward-looking potential of
        electronic music while also drawing from generations of folk traditions.

items.title:
Nadah El Shazly
        –
        Laini Tani
items.label: One Little Independent
items.description:
Spanning past and present with a singular unearthliness, Nadah El
        Shazly's filmic scope on Laini Tani reveals the intense curation
        of an auteur. The album opens with a deceptively dream-pop bent before
        blossoming into a genre-spanning ride of industrial, classical and
        trip-hop. Her lyrics come alive with the hustle and bustle of Cairo (her
        hometown), her interiority and the interplay between the two.

items.title:
DJ Bone –
        DJ Bone XXXV: The End of Never
items.label: FURTHER
items.description:
In late May, DJ Bone decided to put out a whopping six releases to
        celebrate his accomplishments: five years of his FURTHER label, 30 years
        of his Subject Detroit label, 35 years in the music industry and, most
        importantly, his 55th birthday.
        The End of Never, the first of the six, offers more energy than
        his previous LPs, crackling with the futurism and thrust of the best
        Detroit techno. Take "Critical," which consists of little more than
        drums, a squelchy, two-chord Juno stab and hip-hop-coded vocals. It
        feels like mainlining a double espresso.

items.title:
Polygonia
        –
        Dream Horizons
items.label: Dekmantel
items.description:
Polygonia's latest unfolds like the sci-fi film
        Annihilation, where the DNA of living organisms is refracted and
        reconstituted into forms that are mutated and haunting yet somehow still
        gorgeous. Her soft-focus atmospheres offer moments of introspection,
        while earthly textures become anchors as she observes her ephemeral
        worlds. In these dreamscapes, highlights like "Gate To Amygdala" and
        "Hidden Blue" reveal just how intricate the Munich-based act's sonic
        craftsmanship is.

items.title:
Purelink
        –
        Faith
items.label: Peak Oil
items.description:
Purelink's new album of glitch and ambient techno rewards listeners
        willing to sit with quiet. Over time, the record slowly reveals
        intricate networks of sound amid an unwavering blanket of echo and
        barely-there feedback. The group also fold vocals from selected
        vocalists—Loraine James and poet Angelina Nonaj—into the mix. Opening
        track "Looked Me Right In The Eye" conjures a soporific sense of
        nightfall. On "Circle Of Dust," it almost sounds like the trio is
        volleying a ball between them, a technique more befitting a jam band
        than an electronic group.

items.title:
Nick León
        –
        A Tropical Entropy
items.label: TraTraTrax
items.description:
When Joan Didion set her sights on Miami during its mid-'80s heyday, she
        looked past the pastel-hued condos to find a new form of hybridised
        decay—attempts to mask state-sanctioned corruption behind the veneer of
        a tropical paradise. It's an unexpected yet totally apt point of
        reference for Nick León, a proud ambassador of Miami's dance music
        scene. But A Tropical Entropy is far from a dour outing. "Ocean
        Apart," for instance, almost becomes a full-blown EDM rager, but backs
        away before the catharsis of a major drop.

items.title:
naemi –
        Breathless, Shorn
items.description:
Following up the excellent
        Dust Devil, Berlin-based artist naemi releases a slimmer album, with a tighter
        list of contributors. Baptist Goth delivers feathery indie vocals, and
        Foamy transports you to a dingy DIY venue via scruffy drums. The record
        still highlights naemi's strengths in shoegaze and hazy guitar, while
        also touching on ethereal folk ("fearless girl") and metallic jungle
        ("maze").

items.title:
Facta –
        GULP
items.label: Wisdom Teeth
items.description:
On GULP, Wisdom Teeth boss Facta weaves chillout music into his
        signature bright melodies and skippy rhythms. R&B-inspired synths
        lacquer house percussion on the cruising "Skyline 4." "terminal" is
        sedated airport music, while "BDB" dials up the energy with clubby
        2-step.

items.title:
Isabella Lovestory
        –
        Vanity
items.label: Giant Music
items.description:
Isabella Lovestory's second album shows the range she's developed since
        her debut, Amor Hardcore. On highlights like lead single
        "Telenovela," her braggadocious reggaeton is infused with a theatrical
        narrative, while further in, she sings glamorously over loungey disco
        ("Pill") and raps over sparkly Y2K hip-hop on "Gorgeous."

items.title:
Simo Cell
        –
        FL Louis
items.label: TEMET Music
items.description:
On FL Louis, Simo Cell channels the garish energy of one of
        bloghouse's capital cities, Paris. These four tracks are a carnival ride
        through the past two decades of dance music—from French touch to
        dubstep, hip-hop to deconstructed club—stitched over erratic drum
        programming and imbued with bloghouse's cocaine-fueled irreverence.

items.title:
Lauren Duffus
        –
        Can's Gone Warm
items.label: Select Few
items.description:
These six tracks are a brilliant melange of trip-hop, grime, R&B and
        guitar music. "Super" shows off clicky percussion and icy synths,
        springing around the South London artist's reverbed falsetto in a way
        that recalls Fade to Mind-era Kelela. The vocal hook of "N.U.M.T.E.,"
        another clear highlight, channels the serpentine sensuality of '90s R&B
        before diving into ricocheting jungle.

items.title:
BAMBII –
        INFINITY CLUB II
items.label: Because Music
items.description:
Arriving two years after the first, BAMBII's second volume of
        INFINITY CLUB takes us all around the Caribbean with a
        star-studded roster of vocalists. "NSYNC," featuring Skrillex
        collaborator BEAM, is dancehall with a '00s twist. Brazilian artist
        LYZZA brings baile funk to "Blue Sky." And "Mirror," with Jessy Lanza
        and Yaeji, explores guitar-led pop amid outbursts of jungle.

items.title:
bastiengoat
        –
        Liquor Store Lime
items.label: Self-released
items.description:
How many times can 50 Cent's "In Da Club" be reworked for peak time?
        bastiengoat's "Home Burden" makes a damn good case for it. Once the
        reflective piano chords come in, you're reminded how the Bay Area
        producer can turn basic samples from water into wine.

items.title:
Surusinghe –
        i can't remember the name of this, but that's ok
items.label: dh2
items.description:
Surusinghe's dynamic, percussive tunes instantly teleport you to a
        strobe-lit dance floor. With a short, chipmunk sample looped over synths
        that sound like rubber bands, "FTRW!" is the kind of track that lights
        up festival stages. "Wolfgang" is similarly energetic. As a tunnelling
        loop bubbles up at lightning speed, techno kicks transport the cut to
        the dark, shadowy corners of the club.

items.title: The Wednesday Alternative Mix
items.description:
Look for an apt description of FFAN's style, and "adult-oriented disco"
        might fit best. It was originally coined to
        describe
        the music of Prins Thomas, whose tracks appear in this high-energy hour
        of The Ransom Note's Wednesday Alternative Mix series. The term feels
        just right for the Nyapi owner's eclectic sound. Across the hour-long
        mix, the Seoul-based DJ maintains a medium tempo, blending dark,
        flamboyant elements—from gothic synths and vocals to acid flourishes and
        suspense-filled drum arrangements.

items.title: Oceanic at Garage, Horst Arts & Music 2025
items.description:
One of the most memorable sets at this year's Horst Arts & Music wasn't
        on the festival's main stage, but its most intimate. In a low-lit corner
        of Garage, Oceanic delved into the wonky side of house music—strange
        vocals, minimal classics and beatless synth workouts. Featuring Laurie
        Spiegel and Skee Mask, the two-and-a-half-hour recording is melodic and
        weightless in parts, heavy and heady in others—but consistently
        elevating.

items.title: GYSTMIX-030
items.description:
Gay Felony is the alias of Melody Scallion, a longtime force in LA's
        dance music underground. Her sets, like this one for the increasingly
        essential Gyration Station series, are deliberately fast and ecstatic,
        moving through upbeat house selections that wouldn't be out of place in
        an Eris Drew and Octo Octa set. It's an intentional choice to queer the
        floor, collapse binaries and dive headfirst into transfuturism.

items.title: Everything reminds me of dubstep pt. III - curated by livwutang
items.description:
Everything reminds me of dubstep is a series that reimagines the UK-born
        genre through its softest moments—the bridges, outros and tender
        undercurrents. For the third instalment, New York-based DJ (and former
        Resident Advisor staffer) livwutang curates a playlist which
        Beatrice M. then assembled into a mix that foregrounds lush, sweeping
        melodies and emotional density. It's a love letter to the genre's
        range—a reminder that dubstep has always been just as much about feeling
        as force.

items.title: ITPS117
items.description:
Commodo's entry into the Ilian Tape podcast vault spotlights the darker
        fringes of bass music. Featuring TRG's "Broken Heart," Rene Wise's
        "Don't Care" and Mala's "Tombstone," his selections are simply bananas,
        running the gamut from techno rippers to dubstep classics and back. He
        includes several of his own productions—most notably, "Shake and Lurk"
        and "89! Gloom!" from a new EP with Gantz—alongside standout picks from
        artists like TMSV, Hijinx and Kuedo.

items.title: Rio 015 - Adi (recorded live at Bonanza 2025)
items.description:
Set in the lush surroundings of Buritaca, Colombia, Bonanza Festival has
        quietly become a key meeting point for Latin America's electronic
        community. Adi, born in Bogotá and now based in Brussels, has built a
        steady following for her blends of trippy house, electro and techno,
        tinged with acid. Taking over from Nicolas Lutz at 7:30 AM, she kept up
        the momentum with nimble rhythms and just the right amount of sleaze,
        squelch and restraint.

items.title: IT.podcast.s14e04: BMG at No Way Back 2025
items.description:
If Detroit's Movement Festival is a pilgrimage, then No Way Back is its
        sacred ritual. The annual Tangent Gallery gathering is special for
        everyone involved, chiefly the DJs, who always go the extra mile. Motor
        City legend BMG is no exception. This year, he debuted fresh hardware
        remasters and exclusive edits of Pink Floyd, 808 State and Aphex Twin,
        alongside forthcoming releases on Interdimensional Transmissions. As he
        said himself: "We start at the Tangent and end up travelling to the
        other side of the universe."

items.title: Deep House, Electronic & Broken Beats on a Tuktuk
items.label: Pam Anantr
items.description:
On Bangkok's TukTuk Radio, DJs play CDJs while cruising around the Thai
        metropolis on a tuk-tuk. The latest episode features Pam Anantr, a
        staple of the local club scene and cofounder of
        Salon Kiku. For a captivating hour, she indulges in broken drums from the likes
        of Mia Koden, plus jazzy house à la Paul Johnson and Pal Joey.

items.title:
Various –
        Planet Mu 30
items.label: Planet Mu
items.description:
The influential UK label marks 30 years with a typically eclectic,
        forward-facing trip through footwork, IDM and experimental. Zoning in on
        new unheard music from its 2025 band of musical freaks,
        Planet Mu 30 is loaded with the kind of leftfield experimentation
        that established its reputation. Expect heaters from RP Boo, Traxman,
        Jlin and more.

items.title:
Erika de Casier
        –
        Lifetime
items.label: Independent Jeep Music
items.description:
The alt-R&B artist's fourth album crystallises her tastemaking without
        ever sacrificing style for substance. Written and produced entirely on
        her own, Lifetime is a confidently self-referential record that
        goes with her own flow, settling into sensual downtempo that somehow
        manages to sound both effortless and studied.

items.title:
Kara-Lis Coverdale
        –
        From Where You Came
items.label: Smalltown Supersound
items.description:
Kara-Lis Coverdale's first album in eight years draws heavily from
        programmatic music, a classical style that gained traction in the
        Baroque period. Each song shares dozens of small stories, filled with
        enough peaks and troughs to fill out a beat sheet for the next season of
        The White Lotus.

items.title:
PinkPantheress
        –
        Fancy That
items.label: Warner Records
items.description:
Fancy That is a cheeky romp through UK dance pop history, sipping
        from everything on the Y2K singles charts—from the digital glut of
        Spiceworld to the trance vortexes of Frankfurt producer Spicelab.
        Colours get dialled up to maximum saturation as PinkPantheress splashes
        into full-hearted, unguarded pop for the first time.

items.title:
Model/Actriz –
        Pirouette
items.label: True Panther Sounds
items.description:
Casting aside their previously hard-edged bravado, New York band
        Model/Actriz embrace vulnerability with confidence and a newfound
        lightness on Pirouette. They've dubbed it a dance pop album,
        manually aping drum machines and introducing earworm hooks. The LP still
        has the band's no wave dissonance and twisted bacchanalian throb, but
        some seriously operatic vocal moments demonstrate a real willingness to
        take the armour off.

items.title:
Surgeon –
        Shell~Wave
items.label: Tresor
items.description:
What does techno mean to a 30-year-plus stalwart of the sound? For
        Surgeon, it's a spiritual collaboration between humans and technology,
        past and future. Shell~Wave bottles his personal experiences with
        his machines and delivers it to listeners with the improvisation of a
        free jazz musician.

items.title:
Various –
        Road Fever: New Generation Carnival Riddims From St. Lucia And
          Dominica
items.label: Soundway Records
items.description:
This compilation is an invaluable snapshot of two rising genres—St.
        Lucia's Dennery segment and Dominica's bouyon—dissected to a clinical
        degree. Road Fever is a testament to the Caribbean's continuous
        innovation, ingenuity and celebration of its ever-evolving musical
        culture.

items.title:
Shanti Celeste
        –
        Romance
items.label: Method 808
items.description:
"Can we get closer?" So asks Shanti Celeste over a shimmery
        bassline on "Unwind." On her second album, the British-Chilean producer
        puts her vocals front and centre for the first time, fusing garage, R&B
        and her signature house with a disarming sense of intimacy, both on and
        off the dance floor.

items.title:
OSSX –
        WORLD KEEPS TURNING
items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Prolific New Jersey trio OSSX are keenly attuned to the needs of the
        dance floor. Their debut album wholeheartedly bolsters this reputation,
        spreading their signature East Coast club sound—hollering vocals,
        shuttling snares—over samples of '90s hits that almost seem too obvious
        (look out for Suzanne Vega's "Tom's Diner," Cheryl Lynn's "Got to Be
        Real"). But in OSSX's hands, pop and R&B become club tools that any
        smart DJ will keep in their kit.

items.title:
Chaos In The CBD
        –
        A Deeper Life
items.label: In Dust We Trust
items.description:
From the bossa nova swing of "Mountain Mover" to the slinky downtempo of
        "Barefoot On The Tarmac," A Deeper Life is breezy, crisply
        produced music to loosen your collar to.

items.title:
Smerz –
        Big city life
items.label: ESCHO
items.description:
On Big city life, Smerz finds a cohesive sound that elevates
        their place in the Norwegian experimental scene. By leaning into
        guitars, hook-driven R&B and low-slung electro, they've strengthened
        their storytelling chops (as on the string-led "Feisty" and the romance
        of "You got time and I got money") while keeping their loveable knack
        for weirdness.

items.title:
J. Albert –
        Return To Sender
items.label: Self-Released
items.description:
New York producer J. Albert returns with his first proper album in
        years. The focus? Stoner ambient and dub techno. "Warped Mirror" offers
        glimpses of his lo-fi house past with deep house chords and brittle dub
        architecture. "22" cuts through the vibey feel, descending into an
        industrial ambient abyss where synths snap and hiss like high-voltage
        power lines. One to sink into.

items.title:
Ron Trent
        –
        Lift Off
items.label: Rush Hour Music
items.description:
Ron Trent's first album since
        2022 builds on the smooth,
        jazzy house that he's so loved for. Centreing bright synth lines and
        cruising funk tempos, Lift Off slowly dials up the energy levels,
        all while maintaining the Chicago legend's signature sultry cool.

items.title:
Anthony Naples
        –
        Scanners
items.label: ANS Recordings
items.description:
There's plenty to marvel at on Anthony Naples' sixth album,
        Scanners. "Lifetimes" has an R&B feel to its gilded chords and an
        East Coast shuffle to its booming drums. "Bounce" is slick, tunnelling
        techno. "Somebody"'s stuttering, detuned piano notes slip intricately in
        and out of a punchy four-to-the-floor beat. The rhythms are tight and
        addictive from the start, the melodies keeping you tethered to the
        endless groove.

items.title:
Colombian Drone Mafia, Gibrana Cervantes –
        Memoria
items.label: Ambie—Tón
items.description:
TraTraTrax cofounder Nyksan is next up on ambient sub-label, Ambie—Tón.
