items.label: Warp Records
items.description:
Warp RecordsKelela - Raven
At the shows for her new album, Kelela stood alone onstage. This was a deliberate choice, she explained, to have everything stripped back so audiences could see her—and hear her—for all she was. But up there, the blue lights around her dimmed, it was clear that her solitary figure also reflected her more bitter-than-sweet struggles against what she described as "male stoicism." This remark came from the revelations she had while reading The Will to Change, an investigation of men, masculinity and love by the radical Black feminist scholar bell hooks. Her epiphany was painstakingly reflected in the dancehall derivation "On The Run": "You get around enough / Too busy actin' tough / Give me a softer side / I won't wait all night." Patriarchal culture doesn't only hurt women, Kelela discovered—it also restricts the way men are able to explore intimacy and achieve wholeness for themselves.

I saw Kelela perform in Berlin. 13 of Raven's 15 tracks were produced there, and it shows. There's a sorrow and solemnity woven into the city's monochromatic corners that echo through Raven, like a pebble rattling in an empty aluminium can. Even the title track is underpinned by a spacious yearning, as if on the brink of a breaking point—"Took all my labour / Don't tell me that I'm strong," she sings, before gradually trotting into a heaving 4/4 beat, a subtle nod to clubbing as escapism. By the album's conclusion, "Far Away," Kelela finds her deliverance in the form of honeyed ad-libs undulating over sounds of crashing waves, as if signalling that with enough time and perspective, all pain can be alchemised into pure spirit. -Whitney Wei

items.text: Caroline Polachek - Desire I Want To Turn Into You
items.label: Perpetual Novice
items.description:
Perpetual NoviceCaroline Polachek - Desire I Want To Turn Into You
Diving headfirst into the delusion and madness that accompanies the all-consuming feeling of romantic and sexual passion, this unapologetically raw album leaves no stone unturned in its portrayal of emotional intensity. Through visceral lyrics that underline the idea of desire as a truly physical sensation, the ex-Chairlift vocalist sings of self-indulgent surrender to a lover without the slightest care of appearing desperate or needy. But it's the production—from Polachek and Danny L. Harle—that truly makes this a multifaceted pop record: feathery drum & bass, flamenco, dreamy rock and bassy R&B bops add to the physicality of Polachek's feelings, pushing her theatrical vocals outside of the shielded realm of inner thoughts and into the material world. -Nyshka Chandran

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: James Holden - Imagine This Is A High Dimensional Space Of All Possibilities
items.label: Border Community
items.description:
Border CommunityJames Holden - Imagine This Is A High Dimensional Space Of All Possibilities
James Holden's music has always been otherworldly. Raised on pirate radio, folktronica, free jazz and everything in between, he conjures up mythical fairy tales where flickers of dance music past meander into pastoral soundscapes. This all culminated with Imagine This Is A High Dimensional Space Of All Possibilities, which marks a welcome return to the club for Holden—or his version of it, anyway. Recognisable dance music tropes (hints of dub techno, echoes of house, microdoses of rave) nestle into the rich and complex instrumentation that gives all of Holden's music its distinctive flair. If Jon Hassell had been born four decades later and became hooked on acid house, this is the album he would've wanted to write. -Henry Ivry

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Domino
items.description:
DominoTirzah - trip9love...?
Over the past decade, childhood friends Tirzah Maston and Mica Levi have become a quietly formidable power duo (in leftfield music circles, at least). On their latest LP of heart-tugging R&B, Levi's tough 808s and trilling piano sketches hold a steady, unrelenting pace while Tirzah pours her heart into 11 rough-and-ready love songs. All the familiar hallmarks of Tirzah are there—understated vocals and a sound rooted in "disarming simplicity"—but here everything is notched up to a new, more physical intensity. Each track packs a smouldering punch and Levi's distorted piano melodies on tracks like "F22" and "Promises" have Grand Cru earworm qualities. The album turns Tirzah and Levi's often ramshackle songs into a steamrolling train that tugs at the heartstrings all the harder, while still holding onto the lightweight feel that makes all of the project's music so enchanting. -Conor McTernan


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Self-releasedRegal86 - La Onda
If there was one trend in techno to note this year—aside from "fast"—it was hardgroove, a taut and loopy style originally pioneered in the '90s and making one hell of a comeback on dance floors across the Americas and Europe in 2023. Regal86, a buzzy producer from Monterrey makes all kinds of music, but he's particularly good at hardgroove. His album La Onda landed at the perfect time to take the revival to the next level. With breathless sequencing and expert programming, this is hard, fast dance music that doesn't bludgeon you over the head, but instead invites you to dance and get lost in its intricacies. And with trip-hop breaks and clever interludes, La Onda works as an album through and through, recalling some '90s techno greats with real finesse. -Andrew Ryce

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: XL Recordings
items.description:
XL RecordingsOvermono - Good Lies
Going from throwing makeshift parties deep in the woods to sold-out global tours, Overmono's ascent is long overdue. After a decade of passionate grinding in the underground, their debut album, Good Lies, makes a well-earned victory lap. Boundless euphoria is the goal and '90s rave and Burial-adjacent techno are the means—including radio-ready vocal chops from the likes of Tirzah, Slowthai and CASISDEAD. Having penned a vibrant love letter to both the past and present of UK dance music, the two brothers from rural Wales establish themselves as authors of its future. -Emeka Okonkwo


Listen:
Bandcamp

items.text: James Blake - Playing Robots Into Heaven
items.label: Columbia
items.description:
ColumbiaJames Blake - Playing Robots Into Heaven
Don't call it a comeback… but James Blake's latest album kind of feels like a comeback. He's spent years perfecting an electronic singer-songwriter style that has seen him working with everyone from Kendrick Lamar to Frank Ocean. On Playing Robots Into Heaven, he dives head first into club music and delivers some of his canniest fusions yet. The melodrama and introspection is still there, but on tracks like the thrilling "Loading" or the surging house of "Fall Back," his words—and dextrous vocal chopping—gains a whole new power, especially when sandwiched between woozy ballads like "Fire The Editor." In other words, it's the best of both worlds. -Andrew Ryce

Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Mr. G - Pearls Don't Lay On The Shore
items.label: Childhood
items.description:
ChildhoodMr. G - Pearls Don't Lay On The Shore
According to Mr. G, Pearls Don't Lay On The Shore is what happens when he makes music from the soul. Over 14 tracks, the funky tech house he built his name on makes room for plaintive New Age delights and darkly tinted downtempo. It's a turbulent, subaquatic voyage that reaches even murkier depths than 2021's The Forced Force Is Not The True Force. Where the sonar-guided ominousness and broad sawtooth basslines on tracks like "No Safe Zones" evoke the ocean floor, the searching keys and trance-inducing hand drums on tracks like "For Those Who Have Lost" still reach for the cosmos. A riveting ode to his mother Sylvia, Pearls Don't Lay On The Shore is Mr G. at his most soul searching and experimental. -Emeka Okonkwo

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Live From Earth
items.description:
Live From EarthDJ Gigola - Fluid Meditations
Aside from being a phenomenal debut album, Fluid Meditations is compelling because it embodies the enduring influence of wellness culture on dance music. The album is a tropical, at times ghostly take on modern New Age electronic music, with vocal techniques that recall Voice Actor's sibilant whispers and the guided meditation of DJ Python's memorable 2020 cut "ADMSDP." The album picks up in its second half, the meditation laid underneath hoover synths and spritely trance, making it a record that travels well from day into night. -Kiana Mickles

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Step Ball Chain
items.description:
Step Ball ChainMaara - The Ancient Truth
Maara has a preternatural sense for interstellar atmospheres that are also suited to intimate home listening. Her debut album yawns to life with loose breakbeats over a lattice of whispery vocals, and eventually spins out into another realm of glimmering downtempo music. A special kind of self-assured ease in drifting into the unknown exists here. The Ancient Truth feels like a period of focused introspection, full of lush pads and pensive basslines, that reveals an inner world even more vast and mystical than how it first seems (just after the beat drops on the title track, a "wake up, wake up" chirps in the distance). All it takes is a wide-eyed sense of wonder to appreciate Dunbar's gentle yet far-flung exploration. -Whitney Wei

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Tresor
items.description:
TresorSurgeon - Crash Recoil
On Crash Recoil, Surgeon's first album in five years, he said he tried to bring his live improvisational sets to the studio for the first time, "in the same way that bands tour songs before going into the studio to record an album." The Detroit-indebted swing of earlier albums is subdued to a simmering pulse, and Surgeon's longtime influences—experimental rock bands Coil and Faust—take centre stage. Spectral pads elongate over crunchy drums. Abrasive melodies appear and fade into the ether. Songs travel with the meandering, liberated structure of music built through feeling instead of dance floor mania, unlocking a new level of depth and nuance in one of the most legendary catalogues in techno. -Kiana Mickles

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Kompakt
items.description:
KompaktWata Igarashi - Agartha
Techno trends come and go, but Wata Igarashi will never go out of style. Cerebral, psychedelic, Rome school—whatever adjective you choose to describe the Japanese producer's music, so long as clubs are willing to stay open for more than 12 hours at a time, there'll always be DJs digging for Igarashi's style of lean, introverted techno. This makes his debut album, Agartha, such a curveball. The LP fuses Berlin school Krautrock and fourth world ambient with the odd bit of Detroit electro and techno, both unexpected and unbelievably impressive. Igarashi has always been more than "just" a techno producer, but Agartha solidifies his reputation as a true electronic music visionary. -Henry Ivry

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Yves Tumor - Praise a Lord Who Chews But Does Not Consume
items.label: Warp Records
items.description:
Warp RecordsYves Tumor - Praise a Lord Who Chews But Does Not Consume
It's hard to believe Yves Tumor's Praise A Lord Who Chews But Which Does Not Consume; (Or Simply, Hot Between Worlds) came out in March—it already feels like one of those timeless cult albums fans know inside-out. In recent years, the US artist has swirled around the smokey, delay-drenched periphery of '90s alt rock. Here, they jump right in, heels first, to riff on alt-rock greats like Jimi Hendrix ("Heaven Surround Us…"), The Strokes ("Operator") and even prime-era Bloc Party ("In Spite of War"), with epic guitar leads and explosive drum patterns as the rushing, technicolour backdrop to Tumor's angsty lyricism. -Sophie McNulty

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Planet Mu
items.description:
Planet MuNondi_ - Flood City Trax
Johnstown, Pennsylvania, suffered devastating floods in 1889, 1936 and 1977. What was once a city with a thriving steel mill and coal industry was left in tatters alongside a draining population. According to local producer Nondi_, those who were left behind—like herself—now live in limbo, floating between boredom and a constant fear of when the next flood will strike. On her ambient juke LP Flood City Trax, cutesy, cotton-cloud FX meet frenetic footwork percussion to convey a conflicting and distant depiction of a place that's been left for dead by the rest of the world, yet stubbornly lives on. -Joseph Francis

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Kynant Records
items.description:
Kynant RecordsPaul St. Hilaire - Tikiman Vol.1
It's been 17 years since his last album, but Paul St. Hilaire remains dub techno incarnate. The OG producer and Basic Channel collaborator resurfaced this March with nine exquisite tracks that show off his mastery of subtle, politically charged grooves. Touching on downtempo, minimal techno, roots reggae and dancehall, Tikiman Vol.1 runs the gamut genre-wise while delivering concise commentary on displacement, education and memory. Fuzzy dub tones on "Keep Safe" and "The Weather Man" give way to chuggier cuts like "In Door," with St. Hilaire's mesmeric vocals and streamlined basslines acting as key transition tools throughout. Still instantly recognisable, the dub techno MC has a way of making dreamy, '90s-style atmospheres feel fresh with carefully leftfield touches. -Nyshka Chandran

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Awe
items.description:
AweLaurel Halo - Atlas
Laurel Halo never loved playing the piano, but she returned to it just before the pandemic. And then she was kind of stuck with it, until it became her defining instrument of the decade so far. On Atlas, her first so-called ambient album, she takes her piano and the sounds of collaborators on strings and explodes it into sonic dust. Those particles are rearranged into gentle compositions that inhale and exhale like a living respiratory system, with melodies that appear like clouds on the horizon before rolling away and letting the music clear up again. Atlas takes the fearless compositional framework of past albums and her ear for slight-but-dazzling melodies and presents them in a new, almost neoclassical way. It's another excellent entry in one of dance music's most wonderfully unpredictable discographies. -Andrew Ryce

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Príncipe
items.description:
PríncipeDJ Danifox - Ansiedade
Traditionally, batida is a sound characterised by a lively interplay of emotions and energies: roiling drums, racing tempos and rousing vocals. Lisbon label Príncipe has long documented the genre's many faces, from electro bangers to housey grooves, and this stunning offering from one of its core members reveals a foggier take. The slow-burning LP unravels like a gentle love letter, pairing intuitive, staccato drums with conversational vocals and lush instrumentation (guitar and woodwinds). There are hints of jazz, trap and dub techno—perhaps a reference to batida's own cross-pollination from various Angolan and Portuguese styles—and a thread of tenderness and toughness. Danifox's lilting melodies wrap batida's bounce into a dulcet, romantic daze. -Nyshka Chandran

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Low Lying Records
items.description:
Low Lying Recordsa.s.o. - a.s.o.
Lewie Day and Alia Seror-O'Neill's debut self-titled LP as a.s.o is one of those albums that anyone with a longing for nostalgia could fall in love with—fans of Mazzy Star, Warp Records devotees, trip-hop lovers. Part of the reason why is because the album's palette sounds eerily familiar, like every phenomenal downtempo album released before the turn of the millennium blended into one. But it's not pastiche: the lyrics feel bitingly modern and the production is taken to outer space in ways their predecessors didn't yet have the language for. And to top it off, Seror-O'Neill's frigid, sultry voice reverberates through it all gracefully. -Kiana Mickles


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Ninja Tune
items.description:
Ninja TuneSofia Kourtesis - Madres
There's a track on Madres, the debut album from Berlin-based artist Sofia Kourtesis, named after the neurosurgeon who saved her mother's life. Kourtesis's music has always been connected to familial relationships—2021's Fresia Magalena EP was named after Fresia (her mother) and Magdalena (the district in Lima where she's from) while reflecting on the death of her father—but with each new record her music becomes an even more personal, ecstatic and richly layered collage. Madres deftly combines house music with field recordings from indigenous communities, the Peruvian cajón drum, clips from a protest against homophobia and pan-Latin American rhythms. Kourtesis makes restorative, kaleidoscopic house music that blooms from her heart and tugs at the strings of others, highlighting the power of dance floor healing.
-Katie Thomas


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music

items.text: Various - Chants Of The Holy Oyster
items.label: Kalahari Oyster Cult
items.description:
Kalahari Oyster CultVarious - Chants Of The Holy Oyster
Chants Of The Holy Oyster celebrates six years of Rey Colino's Kalahari Oyster Cult, documenting the Amsterdam label's increasingly singular footprint on contemporary club music. Connecting the dots between various corners of '90s dance music—from dreamy IDM to spacious electro, squelchy trance to wiggly tech house—Colino's vision updates these sounds, rather than basking in nostalgia. With contributions from best-in-school producers such as Roza Terenzi, Sansibar, Maara, Priori and more, the compilation serves as a great reminder that the fruits of the '90s are still ripe for renovation (and innovation). -Bella Aquilina

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Live From Earth Klub
items.description:
Live From Earth KlubBrutalismus 3000 - ULTRAKUNST
Over the last two years, Brutalismus 3000 have become one of the biggest techno acts in Europe through sheer force of will and attitude. Their music, which they call "anti-techno" or "nu-gabber-post-techno-punk"—and they won't say it, but it's also kind of bloghouse—is confrontational but also funny. They channel the outlandish vibe of early electroclash acts and dress it up in an outfit thrifted from Humana that you might see walking down Warschauer Strasse on a Friday night. Tales of murder, excess and scene-baiting ("Safe Space") are soundtracked by short-circuiting electronics, making for a gleeful LP as giddy as it is confrontational, leaving a path of destruction and laughter in its wake. -Andrew Ryce

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music  / Spotify

items.label: Planet Mu
items.description:
Planet MuMun Sing - Inflatable Gravestone
Inflatable Gravestone, the title of Mun Sing's debut album on Planet Mu, neatly summarises the fantastical world the Giant Swan cofounder operates in: a cold, hard symbol of death is turned into something squashy and playful. The music on Inflatable Gravestone folds listeners into that strange and wonderful land, like jumping on a bouncy castle that deflates and re-inflates without warning. The textures are intense ("Squabble"), the rhythms jolting, swerving and sometimes falling off into oblivion ("Gliding"). And it all ties together with an underlying absurdity ("Spider"). It's a place only a truly brilliant and off-kilter mind could conjure up. -Sophie McNulty

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.text: Natural Wonder Beauty Concept - Natural Wonder Beauty Concept
items.label: Mexican Summer
items.description:
Mexican SummerNatural Wonder Beauty Concept - Natural Wonder Beauty Concept

On their self-titled debut album, Ana Roxanne and DJ Python aim to massage out the beauty in loneliness and alienation. Floating on tides of ambient synths, the duo employ emo rap, synth pop, lucid breakbeat and more to explore the substrates of deep connection and unspoken tenderness. Avant-garde instrumental flourishes seamlessly blend into metropolis-at-night atmospherics. Roxanne's ethereal singing plucks at every fibre of your being, while Python's intricate percussion arrangements are modulated until they begin to trickle like water. These two masters of contemplative, shoegazey electronica come together for a debut that lives up to its name and more. -Emeka Okonkwo

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Parallel Minds
items.description:
Parallel MindsCiel - Homesick
The miracle of globalised contemporary electronic music is how artists have imprinted their own unique cultural identity into their productions. The stylistically and geographically roving debut album from Ciel is one such example, melding downtempo, ambient and electro. Ciel, who was born in Xi'an, China, and came of age in Toronto, based Homesick on eight types of traditional Chinese instruments, each of which correspond to the individual track titles. The most striking among them is the anxious tremble of "Metal," interpolated between syncopated drums, and "Silk," all sly chimes and rotund basslines. Conceptually rich, Homesick embroiders the disparate textures of Ciel's Eastern home and her Western world into one elegant tapestry. -Whitney Wei


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Hessle Audio
items.description:
Hessle AudioPangaea - Changing Channels
Festival FOMO moment of 2023? It's gotta be Ben UFO unleashing Pangaea's "Bad Lines" at Dekmantel. The happy hardcore-inspired anthem was the coda to the UK artist's short but magnificently sweet album, Changing Channels, which nailed the hard-to-wrangle cocktail of silly yet classy. In one fell swoop, Pangaea wrote the tune of the summer, doffed his cap to the hardcore continuum and poked fun at dance music's current obsession with speed and neon sounds—all with a massive smile on his face. -Carlos Hawthorn

Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Wisdom Teeth
items.description:
Wisdom TeethK-Lone - Swells
Swells dropped on July 7th, a few days before I made my annual pilgrimage to Love International festival. In Tisno, the sea sparkles, the air is hot and the buzz of the cicadas in the trees is omnipresent. I listened to the glossy ripples of K-Lone's second album as I lay by the water, felt the sun on my skin and closed my eyes to allow my body to recover from the night before—the setting was just right. There are a couple dance floor-leaning tracks on the LP ("Love Me A Little," "Gel"), but Swells is largely made up of elastic tunes that slip, slide and undulate like the lapping of waves on a shoreline. Eliza Rose's vocal appears in hazy manipulations throughout (most notably on woozy R&B cut "With U"), accompanying colourful tones, melodies that glimmer and chords that melt into each other. -Katie Thomas

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Infine Music
items.description:
Infine MusicDeena Abdelwahed - Jbal Rrsas
Tunisian artist Deena Abdelwahed has a predilection for pulling sonic touchpoints from the MENA region and dissolving them into dense, at times confrontational, productions. Case in point is opener "The Key To The Exit," her interpretation of the EDM-adjacent working class Egyptian genre mahraganat. It's a stunner of jagged synth lines that, in spite of its influences, feels like an electronic cousin to doom metal riffs. "Six As Oil" is just as intrepid. Abdelwahed slings around a fugue of subterranean drones, sustained sirens and tight snares to make for a deliciously anti-authoritarian rallying cry. -Whitney Wei

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Nous'klaer Audio
items.description:
Nous'klaer AudioOceanic - Choral Feeling
Why do we sing? It remains one of the great mysteries of human evolution. But to open your mouth, vibrate your vocal chords and produce musical tones through exalting air is at the core of being human. To do so in unison with others is a tradition that can be traced back time immemorial. On his debut album, Oceanic reimagines choral music for the 21st century, chopping, warping and distorting the voices of 30 friends to create Choral Feeling. Equal parts odd and profound, the vocals are often distorted beyond recognition, whether drawn out into haunting melodies or woven into drum patterns through syncopated rhythms. Oberman stays true to choral music's antiquated roots, producing a capacious vision of human connection, one that is mysterious, kaleidoscopic and fundamentally beautiful. -Bella Aquilina

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Rabid Records
items.description:
Rabid RecordsFever Ray - Radical Romantics
Fever Ray's third album is probably the closest that Karin Dreijer's solo project has come to sounding like The Knife, and that's no bad thing. Across ten outré pop tracks that range from the political to the almost hilariously personal (like when they threaten their child's bully on "Even It Out"), Dreijer belts out some of their catchiest hooks over neon-hued production from Trent Reznor, Nídia, Peder Mannerfelt and more. Where Dreijer's past work has revelled in alien unintelligibility, Radical Romantics puts its journey of self-discovery, emotion and passion out there for everyone to see, in all its pseudo-tropical, plastic-palm-tree and artificial beach glory. -Andrew Ryce


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Peak Oil
items.description:
Peak OilPurelink - Signs
Signs, the stunning debut album from Chicago trio Purelink, occupies a nook all of its own in the broad realm of chill-out music—too feathery to be IDM, yet too alert to be ambient. This dubby netherworld, all gentle donks and silky earworms, evokes masters like Jan Jelinek and Lowtec. There's tension and dialogue. In short, don't be fooled into thinking this is background music—you'll be sitting bolt upright within minutes, marvelling at the wisps, wafts and occasional distant chime. It's all too beautiful to ignore. -Carlos Hawthorn

items.label: Juba
items.description:
JubaFact Mix 878
Zipline through a pastiche of Afro-electronic sounds, both domestic and diasporic. Juba, a British-Nigerian DJ who was recently featured in our newest episode of Soundtracking, cherrypicks from gqom, global club, techno and amapiano (the scene's consistent genre du jour) with an energetic panache more often reserved for dancers in front of the decks. The hour-and-a-half, which "ends on a rhythmic high," in the artist’s own words, boasts cameo tracks from the veritable who's-who of the Black underground: DJ Lag, Anz, DJ Swisha, Griffit Vigo and Juba's close friend and promising talent Gafacci. 

At a most unexpected apotheosis, she tucks in a tasteful Avicii bootleg by Dee Traits as well as the Pearson Sound remix of Nick León's "Xtasis (feat. Dj Babatr)", AKA RA's track of the year. Both inclusions mirror two ubiquitous trends of 2022: the Latin-infused techno and pop edit predilections of the underground—signifying the savviness of a selector in the know. All in all, the mix delivers an uppercut of infectious optimism in a new chapter defined by post-pandemic growing pains. —Whitney Wei

items.label: Leon Vynehall
items.description:
Leon Vynehallfabric presents
Creative pressure is a very real thing for artists. How does one constantly evolve and meet—even surpass—their best work? Leon Vynehall seems to know the answer. Since 2018's powerful conceptual album Nothing Is Still, the UK musician has matured from a talented club producer into a storyteller par excellence, weaving original and compelling narratives through sound. 2019's RA-recommended DJ-Kicks was one of the best mixes that year. Now, in 2022, he's charted again.

Like DJ-Kicks, fabric presents Leon Vynehall is all about dynamics, except this time the focus is on the club. You'd think that might be restrictive, but Vynehall is a master at finding common threads and energies in disparate musical worlds. Here, work by Mala, A2, Or:la, Ehua, Lady Blacktronika, Commodo, Hagan, Skee Mask and textures from so many other producers hang together in a smoky, soulful soup. The stitching is sublime, the music consistently excellent. At points, it's enough to take your breath away. —Carlos Hawthorn

items.label: Joe Delon
items.description:
Joe DelonLive At Dimensions 2021
Hot take: Joe Delon likes dance music more than just about anyone. He tours all the time, but still finds time to write a regular newsletter about everything going on around him. As a DJ he exudes enthusiasm, playing groovy records that run the gamut from sleek contemporary tech house to old school Italo classics. This live recording from Dimensions captures his range perfectly: he starts low and slow, but just as things get a bit heady, he makes a U-turn with the outrageous vocal track "Adventure" by Eleanor and Shep Pettibone. From there, things dart between the cerebral and the cheesy. Vintage hip house gives way to G-funk-laced electro and acid before dissipating into celestial techno and old school rave. It's hard to imagine that even the security team wasn't losing it during this masterclass in Tisno. —Henry Ivy

items.label: Yumi
items.description:
YumiAccidental Meetings Podcast #72
New York DJ Yumi was probably a new name to a lot of people when they first heard this mix for UK platform Accidental Meetings, but anyone who did listen was probably left hungry for more. This 66-minute journey is the kind of unassuming but carefully built mix that lays eggs in your brain and hatches weeks later. Eventually, before you know it, you'll memorize every transition. Speaking of transitions, they're all remarkably seamless as Yumi blends together odd tracks at various tempos, gradually pulling off a 30 BPM change so impeccably that you barely notice it. Maybe RA staffer livwutang put it best in one of the SoundCloud comments: "dude [this] is fucking wild… im glad im alive to hear this sound." —Andrew Ryce

items.label: D Dan
items.description:
D DanHÖR, January 13 2022

Berlin-based DJ and Mala Junta resident D.Dan had a big year. Seemingly unknown during the recesses of the pandemic, he catapulted to international acclaim in the last 18 months, not only because of his unanticipated glut of speed-demon dance floor releases—all of which skirt the 150 BPM mark—but also because of his position at the helm of a refreshing new trend towards nimble, groovy techno. His HÖR Berlin mix from January this year perfectly encapsulates this style. Minimal yet replete with understated hooks, it layers psychedelic flurries of toms with tribal drums, house vocals and trancey melodic fills. Strategically moving from rhythmic tracks to deep peak-time riffs and back, he showcases here why he's become such a lauded underground tastemaker—and a name to watch. —Chloe Lula

items.label: Quest?onmarq
items.description:
Quest?onmarqJuanita's 063
"Spiraling" is a concept central to quest?onmarq's work. The New York-based DJ hosts a Lot Radio show of the same name, which sees them exploring a vast range of genres, from breaks to gqom, experimental and the harder regions of techno. They are not only technically skilled, but they have also been gifted with an insatiable curiosity about music, which allows them to play pretty much anything. For the 420-themed mix series, Juanita's—a platform on which DJs typically showcase the slower, sweet-tempered end of their collections—quest?onmarq turned to hazy breaks. The windswept mix breezes past early works like Equinox's rattling "Taking Over" to contemporary jungle like "For The Headstrong" by Tim Reaper & Response. It's a tutorial in considered pacing, showcasing how to play fast while maintaining a subdued energy. —Kiana Mickles

items.label: Toumba
items.description:
ToumbaUntitled 909 117
Dubby, dark and loaded with gnarly bassweight, Toumba's Untitled 909 Podcast is a beastly mix that infuses halftime mutations with a sense of industrial-tinged dread. It's a perfect introduction to the Amman-based artist, whose style nods to Nervous Horizon, Hessle Audio (home to his latest EP) and Nyege Nyege Tapes. The up-and-coming producer shows off his love for tectonic basslines, footwork, hiphop, Middle East folk rhythms and hybrid club music from the developing world during this 80-minute session, which features South Korea's NET GALA gqom ensemble Phelimuncasi reworked into a glitchy bricolage, as well as Dua Saleh's delicate trap. Toumba plays for the dance floor, but he's not afraid to indulge in experimental atmospherics and distorted textures either. This sense of adventure makes this mix powerful—and a whole lot of fun. —Nyshka Chandran

items.label: Kilopatrah Jones
items.description:
Kilopatrah JonesHoncho Podcast Series 108
On September 15th, Haitian-born, Queens-based DJ Kilopatrah Jones wrote on Instagram: "When you think of house music, what do you think of? For me, it's house dancing, getting free on the beat with a friend [you] made on the dance floor." The 108th edition of the Honcho Podcast Series, delivered by Jones as a special Pride mix, encapsulates this feeling—the joy of dancing, moving your body in sync with the kindred spirit on the dance floor you met just moments ago. Full of piano riffs, sensual vocals and a whole lot of groove, Kilopatrah Jones's Honcho offering is an hour of brilliant, ecstatic house that will make you dance until you sweat. —Katie Thomas

items.label: Truly Madly
items.description:
Truly MadlyBSU 066
It's possible that Michael Joyce, AKA Truly Madly, is jumping between two or three different tracks in the first six minutes of his Butter Side Up Mix. It's also entirely possible that Joyce owns a 12-inch that somehow overlays sweeping chords with gurning rave stabs, rolling hand drums and short-circuiting electrical currents. The fact that we'll likely never know the answer is part of the fun (plus, it's not like we'd be able to find any of the records he plays anyways). This two-hour treasure trove of all things '90s sees Joyce in particularly bouncy and jubilant form. There are Latin-flavored rhythms, vintage NY vocals, and little bits of proper late night garage. The mixing is seamless without being showy, and Joyce keeps us on the edge of our seats the whole time, wondering what Shazam-breaking gem he'll reach for next. —H.I.

items.label: Jon K
items.description:
Jon KLive From Sugar Hill
Striking twists and turns are what make Live From Sugar Hill such a sharp and dynamic mix worthy of the physical media it was released on. Taken from Jon Kraus's set for Club Night Club at Brooklyn’s Sugar Hill Disco in September 2021, the cassette (released this year) niftily winds through bouts of grime, baile funk, gqom, ballroom and Jersey club like an alpine skier through a mogul field. Moments of more atmospheric, experimental tunes tease respite here and there, but Kraus knows the attention span of a dance floor all too well. On Live From Sugar Hill, a volley of breaks or a wall of kick drums is always only just around the corner. —Joseph Francis

items.text: Nick León feat. DJ Babatr - Xtasis
items.label: TraTraTrax
items.description:
TraTraTraxNick León feat. DJ Babatr - Xtasis
If 2022 belongs to anyone, it's Nick León. The Miami producer is at the forefront of a new wave of 305-area artists who fuse together the city's unique tapestry of Hispanic cultures—and its deep connections to Latin America—with its robust dance music history. León specifically mixes influences from reggaeton and perreo into what is sometimes termed "Latin tribal techno," but whatever you want to call it, there's no denying the appeal of "Xtasis," the track most of us heard out on dance floors more than any other, by a country mile.
 
"Xtasis," a collaboration with Venezuelan raptor house pioneer DJ Babatr, is a good example of the intercontinental cross-pollination happening within this scene. The percussion plays a trick, both four-on-the-floor and broken at the same time, at a chemically-enhanced pace with distant vocal wails that add a lysergic flair. But "Xtasis"—and its accompanying Pearson Sound and Doctor Jeep remixes—really clicks with the old-school organ bassline that drops in at about the two-minute mark. It's something so simple, so familiar and, frankly, genius, that by the time the kick drum drops back in, the room should be in a frenzy. If it isn't, then you're probably in the wrong place. —Andrew Ryce
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Warp Records
items.description:
Warp RecordsKelela - Washed Away
It's a special, and rare, moment when music drops and completely disrupts the flow of the internet. This was the case with Kelela's "Washed Away," her first single since she put out her acclaimed debut album Take Me Apart five years ago. During the hiatus, she looked inward and studied literature on misogynoir, Black labour and racial capitalism. Suffused in hazy pads and reverbed vocals that sound more like mantras than vocal refrains, "Washed Away" could be perceived as the release of all this collective pain. In a recent interview with Dazed, Kelela described the single as a "heart check-in," a song recorded to "send out a clear message to Black people, who are my core audience and who I intend this music for, that you n***as are worthy." Message received. — Kiana Mickles
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Voam
items.description:
VoamRhyw - Honey Badger
On paper, "Honey Badger" shouldn't work. Its main drum line moves in and out of time with the impatience of a toddler hammering at a sequencer. The sole synth—the closest the track has to a melody—is aggressively abrasive, as if it were made from a substance somewhere between quicksand and sandpaper. But I'll be damned if it isn't one of the catchiest tracks I've heard all year. Undeniably weird, but equally infectious, if you heard the track out (and odds are you did if you went to a festival this summer), it sent every crowd into full blown meltdown. Walking away from any set where it was deployed meant that there were punters with their heads still spinning trying to shriek along to those metallic snares. —Henry Ivry  
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: AD 93
items.description:
AD 93A+A - Eternal September
Both times I heard "Eternal September" this summer I didn't know what it was. On each occasion, it was sunrise at a festival, those blissful hours when time seems to stand still as the sky changes from milky to glowing. It's an ideal track for those hazy moments, with swathes of lush organ chords and fluttering high notes that swoop around like birds with silk wings. When Avalon Emerson and Anunaku (AKA TSVI) shared the upcoming release online, Midland commented on the former's Instagram saying: "I have played these songs and had a nice time while doing so!" To which I thought: I have danced to these songs and had a nice time while doing so! —Katie Thomas
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Livity Sound
items.description:
Livity SoundDJ Plead - Come Quick
DJ Plead usually plays and produces slick, percussive zingers that meld traditional rhythms from the Middle East with high-tempo dance music. But on his second offering for Livity Sound, the Nervous Horizon core member switches out his frenzied pace for a more pared-down tone. Drums remain his core ingredient but the mood is more whimsical, making the record feel more like a score to a picnic in the park rather than a party. Despite its light-hearted nature, "Come Quick" is still loaded with sharp corners and jolting melodies—a true day to dusk record. —Nyshka Chandran
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: More Time
items.description:
More TimeAhadadream - Spaceship
Imagine Lunice, DJ Lag, Roska and Benga linking up for a recording session, and you start to get a sense of what "Spaceship" sounds like. On an EP filled with massive, celebratory tracks, Ahadadream's "Spaceship" was colossal. Every few bars it felt like he was shifting his reference points. What starts as a UK-funky-meets-gqom hybrid morphs into a dubstep throwback with its airy, descending melody. But then the xylophone chimes and upbeat snares capture the maximalism of TNGHT records. As the inadequacy of comparison should make clear, though, "Spaceship" is sui generis, announcing the arrival of a new torchbearer for all things big and bassy. —H.I. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Voam
items.description:
VoamPariah - Caterpillar
It's been a few years since Pariah put out any solo material (he's primarily active as one half of Karenn alongside Blawan). It's been even longer since he released dance music in his own right. Caterpillar, then—which came out in June on Voam, the label he runs with Blawan—is an exciting interruption to this interlude. The hypnotic title track is capital-T techno, but it's heavily textured and nuanced, layering dense modular noodlings with a repeating guttural squelch that sounds more like an off-the-cuff live rip than the polished veneer of most of today's peak-time output. Flanged-out percussion, sizzling analog stabs and a spacey, Pole Group-like synth lead make it the ultimate selection for breaking open a late night set. —Chloe Lula
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Incienso
items.description:
InciensoDJ Python - Angel
At first listen, it's almost unbelievable that Brian Piñyero, better known by his pseudonyms DJ Python and Luis, creates his ambient reggaeton in Ridgewood, Queens. "Angel," off of his EP Club Sentimientos, Vol. 2, has a lot of heart and an even gooier center in its sonic embrace of supple electronics. The ten minute-plus track feels like a weekend-long sojourn into a daydream far from the Halsey L stop, as lush—almost levitating—synth pads breathe deeply around pattering tablas and soufflé riddims. Within its sumptuous depths, there's an earnest, refreshingly unironic appeal to softening, unfolding and tenderness. —Whitney Wei
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Big Saldo's Chunkers
items.description:
Big Saldo's ChunkersSally C - Downtown
When Sally C released the second EP on her label Big Saldo's Chunkers back in April, the tracks had already been doing the rounds for almost a year. Most notable was "Downtown," a big, brash, in-your-face hip house roller that encapsulates what Sally C and her pals mean when they refer to a "chunker." This is functional, no-nonsense dance music that does exactly what it needs to: make your body want to move and groove. The vocal samples are textbook—"Put the needle on the record" and "Do you want to dance?"—but they're a consummate companion for a tune designed to keep the party pumping, proof that less isn't always more. —K.T.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: n goes to infinity
items.description:
n goes to infinityNikki Nair - Step 2
It's hard to imagine following dance music in 2022 and not hearing at least a handful of Nikki Nair tracks. The genre-hopping polyglot was everywhere with everyone, establishing a tight but all-over-the-place sound that blends electro, drum & bass, jungle and footwork. Case in point, "Step 2," which kicked off Nair's own label n goes to infinity. It starts out as hectic uptempo acid jungle track, before crescendoing into a halftime breakdown full of metallic skronks and other aural detritus. It's like walking from a FABRICLIVE night into a Daedalus set circa 2011, and then finishes off with a sprightly techno-jungle jig that feels completely of the moment—an era that Nair is helping define with each new release. —A.R.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Bambe
items.description:
BambeGiGi FM - Manas (PST)
GiGi FM's first signed EP, Magnetite, supposedly holds "spiritually-charged techno mantras." While that may conjure a suite of vaguely spiritual motifs, we get none of that on this kinetic four-tracker. "Manas (PST)" embodies her aesthetic most distinctly, nodding subtly to the artist's sometimes collaborator, Donato Dozzy, with its deeply tribal percussive intro. The rest of the song is beguilingly simple; the propulsive kick-and-tom pattern continues uninterrupted under a single-note cowbell, never changing except for a brief drop about two-thirds in. GiGi FM, an alumnus of both the New York City Ballet and the Alvin Ailey Theatre, has said that the release is a testament to the ritualistic relationship between movement and music. This synergistic dynamic is elegantly elicited on the EP's A2, which is trance-inducingly danceable. —C.L.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
HyperdubHeavee - Sonic Warfare
Heavee's Audio Assault was probably our favourite record on Hyperdub this year, with six tracks of inventive hybrid footwork that capture the label's ethos to a T. The best example was probably "Sonic Warfare"—which shares its name with Kode9's book—a blend of jabby footwork drums, eerie synths and a melodic motif that stutters and fades like electrical interference. —A.R.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Allergy Season
items.description:
Allergy SeasonPhysical Therapy - Emotional Rescue
Physical Therapy spent the last four years working diligently behind the scenes on his label, Allergy Season, as well as releasing records via a slew of his other aliases (Car Culture, DJ Overnite and Fatherhood, his project with Michael Magnan, to name a few). His last release under his original moniker, the 2015 EP Million Years Crushed, was deep, busy and granular. His latest album, Teardrops On My Garage, sounds like a subdued version of Physical Therapy. The garage-inspired chopped vocals are pitched-up and sweet, the melodies resonant and rich. My personal favourite, "Emotional Rescue," is an edit of Tru Faith's "Let The Beat Hit 'Em," that brightens the source material's original vocals with a sparkling melody and rollicking breaks. —K.M.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Self-releasedIsabella Lovestory - Exibisionista
Reggaeton has been undergoing a renaissance in the electronic music world in recent years as artists like Rosa Pistola and the trio Sangra Nueva dissect dembow loops with a toolbox of global club rhythms, producing a kaleidoscope of sub-genres. Among those fringe styles is perreopop, and Isabella Lovestory is one of its leading faces. Here, her sultry lyrics and cam girl aesthetic take on an almost spooky air thanks to producers Nick León and Kamixlo who inject elements of dub and industrial into classic dancehall patterns. Transforming what would have been a regular pop song into a deadly dance floor weapon, the trio are a bright example of reggaeton's futuristic sector. —N.C.
 
Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Rosebud Recordings
items.description:
Rosebud RecordingsEliza Rose & Interplanetary Criminal - B.O.T.A.
If, when one of SASS played "B.O.T.A." at around 8 AM on the Sunday morning of Love International, someone had said to me: "This tune's going to be #1 in the UK," I probably would have laughed and suggested it was time for bed. "B.O.T.A." was the summer's most ubiquitous tune, yes, but in my universe of clubs and festivals. Or so I thought. Skip to Friday, September 2nd, 2022, and Eliza Rose & Interplanetary Criminal had scored the UK's 1,400th #1, the first-ever for a woman British DJ. The percussion is simple and buoyant, the chords are warm and the vocal is catchy as fuck; "B.O.T.A." is a flawless summer bop. —K.T.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: HIJINXX
items.description:
HIJINXXNia Archives - Forbidden Feelingz
British jungle revivalist Nia Archives began her astronomical year releasing a slew of hits du jour and ended it by winning a MOBO award in the ceremony's very first electronic/dance music category. "Forbidden Feelingz," an accelerated Amen break-laden single off her eponymous EP, combines elements of dub and reggae with a distinctly rough-and-ready, old-school UK feel. Nia Archives enthusiastically borrows vintage sensibilities, so the spectre of sound system culture still haunts this one, but to a timeless and earwormy effect. —W.W. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Radiant Love
items.description:
Radiant LoveMaara - Lezzies In A Jacuzzi
Montréal-based Maara has cultivated a fun and femme queer aesthetic that found an appropriate home on the Berlin label Radiant Love. Her EP on the imprint, Goddess Within, features four Goa-leaning trance tunes accompanied by whimsical titles like "Mommy's In Trouble" and "Goddess Within (Give It To Me Daddy)." But it's "Lezzies In A Jacuzzi" that takes the cake for name and substance alike. This anthem layers heavily gated vocals over a throbbing kick and swooning, euphoric pads. Thoughtfully-placed flourishes—a breakbeat fill, a call-and-response arpeggiated synth—elevate this song from cheesy crowd-pleaser to considered dance music production. If the Canadian artist is pointing her ship towards prog, then we're jumping on board. —C.L. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Soundcloud

items.label: Half Baked Records
items.description:
Half Baked RecordsMargaret Dygas - Butterfly Effect
The best minimal tracks are all about attention to detail, so it should come as no surprise that Margaret Dygas' "Butterfly Effect" clocks in at 9:09. The track is immersed in the micro world of details as she dilates and contracts looped conga drums, 909s, a creeping synthline and stormy pressure from her subs. Simple but effective, Dygas approaches these elements with a surgeon's precision as she moves them up and down in the mix. This was Dygas's first 12-inch in over half a decade, a welcome return of one of minimal's weirdos-in-chief. "Butterfly Effect" is a reminder of the strange sense of wonder that only the best minimal can create, where it feels like a loop could go on forever. —H.I. 
 
Listen:
Soundcloud

items.label: Epic Records
items.description:
Epic RecordsUtada Hikaru - Somewhere Near Marseilles
The year's greatest grown-and-sexy jam came out of an unlikely collaboration between the biggest J-pop star of all time and UK house producer Floating Points. Starting with the flicker of an acid line, "Somewhere Near Marseilles" unfolds over 11 minutes of exquisitely produced house, bobbing and glimmering in all the right places. Hikaru sings what feels like three different choruses in a mixture of English and Japanese, glamourously exhorting their lover to meet them in Marseilles as an in-between point between London and Paris. "Let's go fast, then go slow," they repeat over the constantly morphing instrumental track. It's a snippet of luxury and contentment that feels as lush as the song sounds, only improved by Hikaru's impeccable vocal performance—the way she sings, "I'm in London / You're in Paris" is both commanding and effortlessly cool. It's rare that the pleasures of pop and house music come together this well, a cosmopolitan adult contemporary jam made for the most amourous hours of the night. —A.R. 
 
Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Self-releasedKush Jones - BX Bounce
Growing up in New York, it's nearly impossible not to be inundated by different strains of music. The summer streets come alive with reggae and hip-hop; house music wafts in through FM radio or from the cracked window of your longtime neighbour. The vital life force and diversity of the city's sounds has coloured Kush Jones's discography over the years. He typically releases music—drawing from house, jungle, footwork and hip-hop—independently at a fast clip. One of his many works from this year was 6 Days, an EP that was written in, you guessed it, six days. Within a record that shifts rapidly between house and juke, the highlight comes from the pensive pads, idle, honey-sweet melody and subtle percussion on opener "BX Bounce," embodying the very best of New York's intangible cultural heritage. —K.M. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Columbia Records
items.description:
Columbia RecordsBeyoncé - BREAK MY SOUL
When Beyoncé released the first single from her album Renaissance, souls weren't the only thing she broke. The internet, arbiter of half-baked opinions, waxed enthusiastic about house music's reinvigoration within the commercial mainstream. In many ways, "Break My Soul" was formulaic in its hitmaking: it flung gruff yak'ing samples of New Orleans bounce legend Big Freedia ("release ya trade / release the stress / release the love / forget the rest") into a looping bassline inspired by Robin S.'s 1990 smash "Show Me Love"—even tapping into the post-pandemic cultural zeitgeist of saying "fuck it" and quitting your job. But the key to any liberation anthem is confidence, not necessarily originality, and Beyoncé stands on the shoulders of the tried-and-true house heroes that came long before her to successfully ignite the masses. —W.W. 
 
Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Gudu Records
items.description:
Gudu RecordsPeggy Gou - I Go (Soulwax Remix)
In the remix circuit, Soulwax hold a god-tier status. Known for transforming pop, indie and rock classics into expansive dance music epics, the Belgian duo don't take themselves too seriously, tending to zero in on hands-in-the-air euphoria. Their reworking of Peggy Gou's "I Go," is fun-loving to the core, but it's also a potent warehouse banger. Teasing out the original's delicate vocals and retro synths against a fierce, almost mechanical bassline, the remix balances both light and heavy textures with a masterful touch. The breakdowns are on-point, the quirky bird call sample is delightful and there are no boring moments. Soulwax strikes again. —N.C. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Hessle Audio
items.description:
Hessle AudioShanti Celeste - Cutie
As an illustrator, Shanti Celeste has a predilection for bright, happy hues—a blush pink to be precise, if we use her latest EP artwork as a reference. Her Hessle Audio debut adds a welcome splash of colour for the label in the form of two tracks and a Central remix that fizz with winsome positivity. Opener "Cutie" is the standout, idiosyncratically Shanti in its nimble drums and gossamer pads, with a pitched-up, corkscrew of a vocal she recorded herself. It skips along at 140 BPM, settling in the playful sweet spot where heads-down, driving house meets radiant and beatific textures. —K.T.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.text: Skin On Skin - Burn Dem Bridges
items.label: FFRR
items.description:
FFRRSkin On Skin - Burn Dem Bridges
It seems unbelievable that it took someone this long to combine UK drill and techno as perfectly as this. It only took an Australian to do it. In a year that saw his star rise almost absurdly rapidly—and deservedly so—Skin On Skin blew us away with "Burn Dem Bridges," which samples a Sav'o and Horrid1 track and saddles it onto an urgent techno beat with an addictive descending bassline. The whole thing sounds ready to blow at any minute. It's remarkable how a rhythm can change the cadence of a vocal so much, and in Skin On Skin's hands, both drill and techno sound completely fresh, fiery and unstoppable. —A.R. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Mainframe Audio
items.description:
Mainframe AudioTwo Shell - home
Impersonators showed up to their Boiler Room to play a pre-recorded set. Their first interview was taken off the internet in mere hours. Two Shell blew down the doors of 2022. And while some of their gimmicks may split opinions, "home" was a unifying track beloved by the dance music community. The single marked a new direction for the London duo, setting them apart from their peers by creating a completely singular sound where bubblegum pop meets UK bass. A frothing breakbeat at 160 BPM drives the track under its SOPHIE-reminiscent vocal, meanwhile its neon melodies burst like fireworks across the stereo spectrum. "home" will be remembered the way "Hyph Mango" was, marking the entrance into some unknown, but exciting era of UK club music. —H.I. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Self-released
items.description:
Self-releasedKH - Looking At Your Pager
In many ways, 2022 was a massive year for pop music. Underground club producers have long played out cheeky edits of '90s chart-toppers in their DJ sets, but it felt more prominent this year. Under his KH alias, Four Tet brilliantly reworks 3LW's "No More (Baby I'ma Do Right)," autotuning the original lispy vocals against a mean bass synth and a cooing, sparkling melody that feels straight out of a nursery rhyme. It's teen pop in holy matrimony with garage-like beats, plus a faint hint of dubstep—a combination that only someone like Four Tet could pull off. —N.C. 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: All-centre
items.description:
All-centreSHE Spells Doom - Bossano
"Trying to see how African rhythms combine with techno for me is an experiment," said Wamya Tembo AKA SHE Spells Doom in an interview with the Zambian press. "[I like] seeing how far you can push it while still making people want to dance." His latest Afrobeat techno tune, "Bossano," toys with tension with the poise of a tightrope walker. Bursts of percussion ruffle the song’s militant batida march, punctuating every bar of sci-fi synths while also teasing the ruckus of a street party throughout. Like an ellipsis, it brings you to the edge of your seat—or rather, the tips of your toes. —Joseph Francis 
 
Listen:
Bandcamp

items.label: Cómeme
items.description:
CómemePaurro - Galavisión
This lean breakbeat house number serves as a definitive introduction to Paurro's dynamic sound. Combining UK garage and dub influences with psychedelic effects, "Galavisión" is the kind of immersive groove that lends itself to escapist fantasies. Whether hearing it at home or at the club, it's easy to be transported into a lush dream state, one where pleasure and instinct hold more currency than logic. Paurro understands the power of skippy rhythms and low-end frequencies, letting them shine without indulging in too many choppy breaks. With its clear '90s influences and rollicking drums, "Galavisión" is perfect for both peak time and after hours. —N.C.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

items.label: Butter Sessions
items.description:
Butter SessionsJennifer Loveless - Around The World
Galloping, loopy house abounds on this Melbourne producer's EP for home-turf label Butter Sessions. "Around The World" encapsulates the experiences of being a contemporary jetset flâneur, whose lackadaisical saunters are replaced with fast-paced globetrotting. This all seems immediately interpreted through glitchy, disembodied vocals—like filtered announcements over an intercom—and roving, rotund basslines that seem to spend the entire seven-plus minutes attempting to catch up with themselves. Loveless's perspectives bounce—quite literally—in palpable optimism. There's an dazzling array of life out there to see, and simply not enough time to see it all. —W.W.
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Hinge Finger
items.description:
Hinge FingerJoy Orbison - Pinky Ring
No year-end list is complete without a Joy Orbison banger. If the South Londoner's talent is distilling pockets of the hardcore continuum into original bitesize chunks, "Pinky Ring" is a particularly golden nugget. Breaks, drum & bass, post-dubstep, possibly even electro? It's all in there, and yet the track feels anything but retro. Making the past sound fresh and futuristic could well be Joy Orbison's greatest skill. —Carlos Hawthorn
 
Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: D. Tiffany & Roza Terenzi - Edge Of Innocence
items.label: Delicate Records
items.description:
Delicate RecordsD. Tiffany & Roza Terenzi - Edge Of Innocence
Electronic music is something of an ouroboros: sounds hark back to the past as trends recycle in a never-ending loop. The revival of genres like jungle and trance, among others, is proof positive, and the subject of many articles from cultural critics like Simon Reynolds and Mark Fisher. But there's a distinction to be made here. Some artists' chase of rose-tinted nostalgia is nothing more than empty cliché, while others treat their return to a bygone era like a hero's journey—familiar, yet eclipsed by a new, fortified sensibility.

D. Tiffany and Roza Terenzi achieve the ideal balance on their debut album, Edge Of Innocence. It offers a mélange of influences that run the hi-BPM gamut from electro to drum & bass without losing grip of the rippling, psychedelic groove at the core of everything this duo do. "Grains Of Sand" is a case in point, replete with synths that stab through a thicket of lumbering percussion, as is the fittingly named breakbeat bop "Redemption Arc," kitted out with all the sleek dynamism that emerges after a period of dark contemplation. By the end of Edge Of Innocence, you get the feeling that, though the duo are working with well-worn sounds, they've made them all their own. -Whitney Wei

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Warp Records
items.description:
Warp RecordsHudson Mohawke - Cry Sugar
Ross Birchard told us he only works up the nerve to make a solo album about every seven years, and this time it was worth the wait. Like a summary of his history of making weirdo IDM hip-hop and mainstream rap, Cry Sugar is the Glaswegian producer's most epic and wide-ranging LP, chock full of earwormy melodies, left-turn smackdowns and the symphonic pomp-and-circumstance that makes his work one of a kind. You can hear the last ten years of rap music refracted through Birchard's many-sided prism, which is often as funny as it is heavy as it is genius. Like the title implies, Cry Sugar careens from the depressed to the euphoric, each feeling pumped up to the scale of a Marvel movie. -Andrew Ryce

Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Black Rave Culture - Black Rave Culture Vol. 2
items.label: Black Rave Culture Records
items.description:
Black Rave Culture RecordsBlack Rave Culture - Black Rave Culture Vol. 2
One of the most potent club weapons this year, the second offering from Washington DC supergroup Black Rave Culture is a motley crew of historical dance music styles from across the Black diaspora. Representing East Coast club, junglist rhythms and sunny house music with a truly holistic, cross-genre vision, the album teems with grit, unbridled energy and most importantly, power. From the baile funk underpinning "Never Left" to the '90s rave ethos of "Peace Plan," these tracks jump across styles effortlessly, and the fine-tuned production of members Amal, DJ Nativesun and James Bangura holds it all together. -Nyshka Chandran


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Kaoz Theory
items.description:
Kaoz TheoryKerri Chandler - Spaces And Places 
When it comes to making music, too many house and techno legends struggle to hold a candle to their younger selves. Not Kerri Chandler. The US house giant's latest album, Spaces And Places, is a three-hour epic stacked with the kind of tasty grooves and lush instrumentation we've all been gobbling up for 30 years. That its 24 tracks were mostly recorded inside the clubs and venues they pay homage to is both a remarkable feat and a quirky novelty. But it also speaks to something more profound: Chandler's global, enduring popularity. -Carlos Hawthorn


Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Because Music
items.description:
Because MusicShygirl - Nymph
As someone who's been listening to Shygirl since her breakthrough single, "Want More," it might have come as a surprise that the UK artist only released her debut album this year. But as the saying goes, good things take time. This record, aptly titled Nymph—a play on words nodding to the album's whimsical nature and bawdy undertones—is Shygirl in full effect. The vocalist's hooks are tighter than ever, and the ever-expansive production spans pastoral pop, raunchy hip-hop, nostalgic Eurodance and the kind of saccharine hyperpop that trends on TikTok. More than just an excellent first LP, Nymph is a masterclass on collaboration, boasting production credits like Sega Bodega, Arca, Mura Masa and more, whose work melts effortlessly into Shygirl's one-of-a-kind style. -Kiana Mickles


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Carmen Villain - Only Love From Now On
items.label: Smalltown Supersound
items.description:
Smalltown SupersoundCarmen Villain - Only Love From Now On 
Norwegian musician Carmen Villain has a preternatural ability to evoke a sense of cold, uneasy beauty. Her fourth album, Only Love From Now On, features ambient compositions that are often startling in their psychological intrigue. On "Future Memory," Villain expertly braids the sounds of cooing birds, humming flutes and irregular heartbeats to build suspense. "Liminal Space" conjures something similar, except with the inclusion of what seems like faint, irregular footsteps that stumble closer and further away. With its disarming atmospherics, Villain's fourth full-length has nothing to declare—only quiet intensities to whisper. -W.W.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Tresor
items.description:
TresorWaajeed - Memoirs Of Hi-Tech Jazz  
Waajeed's debut on the prestigious Tresor label is a tribute to his hometown of Detroit, as a rousing tribute to both Black leisure and resistance against oppression. Conceptualised with a mini road trip around the Motor City—specifically, from the his own Underground Music Academy to Belle Isle—Memoirs Of Hi-Tech Jazz connects the dots between Detroit's rich musical traditions, encompassing jazz, deep house, minimal techno and marching band music. Even the title, a reference to the Underground Resistance subgroup Galaxy 2 Galaxy, reflects Detroit's storied sonic lineage. Proud, joyous and unapologetically local, Waajeed's love letter to his hometown is packed with velvety tones and lustrous chords that acknowledge the past and pave the way for the future. -N.C.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: PAN
items.description:
PANMarina Herlop - Pripyat
Do you ever wonder how the world looks through a baby's eyes? Everything's new, and nothing makes sense. It's just one brilliant, ever-shifting mirage of colour and sound. Marina Herlop's third album, Pripyat, dazzles in a similar way. Where the Catalan artist's first two records showed off her expert piano playing and freeform, wordless vocals, Pripyat goes a step further into the unknown, patching together her classical training with dissonant electronics, and even weaving in an ancient Indian singing style called konnakol. The album might share its name with a ghost town, but Herlop's Pripyat is alive and bright with boundless imagination. -Joseph Francis


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Whatever The Weather - Whatever The Weather
items.label: Ghostly International
items.description:
Ghostly InternationalWhatever The Weather - Whatever The Weather
While Loraine James was working on her acclaimed 2021 LP Reflections, Loraine James filed away several songs that would ultimately make up her self-titled album, Whatever The Weather. On this meteorology-themed album, James did away with her club sound completely to write a series of ambient tracks distinguished by a worn, melancholy beauty. Here, intermittent rain is depicted as a flurry of lustrous synths, "14°C" is transformed into pensive arpeggios—the playfully jagged IDM she's revered for—and sounds hiccup and stop-start across placid pads all over the LP. As an artist whose main project emphasises tricky beats over strikingly subdued terrain, her pivot to producing a downtempo record—and doing it so well—makes perfect sense. -K.M.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Rush Hour Music
items.description:
Rush Hour MusicSoichi Terada - Asakusa Light
Before this album, Japan's deep house don hadn't released a full-length in over 25 years. But it's abundantly clear that he hasn't lost his touch. There's a light, almost weightless, feel to this 11-track LP as the Tokyo composer and producer shows off his mastery of twinkling chords, spacey disco grooves, vintage synth patterns and video game sounds. Asakusa Light is relatively sparse—even its big-room tracks like "Bamboo Fighter" feature relatively minimal arrangements—which allows his signature melodies to really shine. Graceful and flowing, this is an album that celebrates Terada's craft without feeling like a pastiche of his '90s discography. -N.C.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Dekmantel
items.description:
DekmantelMarcel Dettmann - Fear Of Programming
Marcel Dettmann has always earned more attention for his DJing than his productions, but real fans know that his discography is a treasure trove of dark, detailed techno. Fear Of Programming, which lands on the all-purpose Dekmantel label, is something different: bright, vibrant, even a little funny (thanks to a vocal guest spot from fellow Berghain resident Ryan Elliott). Fear Of Programming is loaded with bold, bassy techno and arresting ambient passages. The real gold is in the hooks, which the spartan but still powerful production emphasizes like a gold frame around a masterpiece painting. It's the work of someone who knows techno inside-out, and knows how to make it compelling without going too far outside the box. -A.R.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Python Syndicate
items.description:
Python SyndicateHagan - Textures
With his debut album Textures, the South London DJ and producer Hagan celebrates the intersecting cultures close to his heart with rich, percussion-driven music. Organic flourishes (Ghanaian group chants, windswept koras and sunny guitar lines, to name a few) broaden the horizons of his historically urban sound palette, and he truly comes into his own as an all-around songwriter. With expertly curated vocal collaborations that reflect on family and faith, elements of gqom, amapiano and highlife, Textures is a transportive ode to the drumming continent, and the meaning of growing up both within and away from it. One moment you're in a lush, jungly landscape, the next you're hustling in the streets of Accra. Textures is more than just African dance music; it's a vibrant amalgamation of all the ingredients and influences that make Brendan Ware Hagan. -Emeka.Okonkwo.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Soma Records
items.description:
Soma RecordsDeepchord - Functional Designs
All of Deepchord's records are good—all of them—but a few are extra special. Functional Designs falls into this category. On first glance, it's not all that different from his countless other LPs. You've got gaseous dub techno beats echoing out into a painstakingly woven web of field recordings, sure. But the melodies are bigger, the drums are heavier and, most importantly, the tracks are separate, each with its own hook, its own uniquely staggered rhythm. Creating another noir-ish world of rainy-night ambiance, Functional Designs is one of Deepchord's most approachable and immersive LPs, gently refurbishing the rock solid formula of dub techno that the Detroit artist has relied on for decades. -A.R.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: One Little Independent
items.description:
One Little IndependentBjörk - Fossora
Björk spent a lot of time dancing and thinking about mushrooms during lockdown. From this—a time she described to Pitchfork as her "fungus period"—came Fossora, the Icelandic vanguard's tenth album. Björk has been making music for over three decades now, and with each record she steps into mystical, uncharted territory, creating work which is ever more beguiling, more avant-garde and always, somehow, even more Björk. On Fossora, Björk sings with a sweeping gravitas over rich woodwinds and distorted gabber beats, the additional instrumentation dancing around her vocal as she muses on the circle of life, nature and her own late mother. Digging her fingers into the earth, Björk unknots tributaries of tangled roots, the crashing drum patterns and complex textures representing the stark, breathtaking topography of her homeland. -Katie Thomas


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Incensio
items.description:
IncensioHuerco S. - Plonk
From the first three seconds of Plonk, you know Huerco S. isn't doing the misty ambient thing again. Plucked strings ping in various directions, like popcorn exploding in a pan. Or, to be more accurate, like parts of a car yawning into gear. The automotive-inspired album, his first in six years, takes the American artist's sound to strange and innovative places—new sounds, unexpected textures, a first-ever vocal cameo. Isn't this what great artists do? Evolve, take left turns and, crucially, always deliver. -C.H.


Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Hyperdub
items.description:
HyperdubKode9 - Escapology
Britain has never felt so close to collapse as it did in 2022. Between prime minister jockeying, mini-budgets and a volatile currency, Steven Goodman returned as Kode9 with a record that made the perfect accompaniment for the instability of the modern UK landscape. Written to accompany an experimental video game about Scotland leaving the union, Escapology operates along a dual axis, at once anxious—filled with eerie bits of sci-fi chatter and dense layers of swelling feedback—but also hopeful, at least when he turns to club tracks. "Uncoil," for example, is a pearl half-covered in sand somewhere between drum & bass and footwork, while "Cross The Gap" uses the negative space of dub to create something glimmering in the weight of the darkness around it. -Henry Ivy



Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: DJ Lag - Meeting With The King
items.label: Ice Drop
items.description:
Ice DropDJ Lag - Meeting With The King
After years pushing the Durban scene and helping to make the sound a global sensation, anticipation for DJ Lag's debut album, Meeting With The King, was sky-high. He used the opportunity to champion his community instead of his own glory, creating a record that is collaborative from start to finish, with a majority focus on artists hailing from his home country of South Africa. Meeting With The King takes the moody sonics of the gqom—born from township house parties—and makes it polished, opulent, even melodic, honouring the origins of the sound while adding catchy elements of amapiano, house, Afrotech and more. The title is boastful, but it's not wrong—on Meeting With The King, DJ Lag stakes his claim and continues his ascent, taking his musical family along for the ride. -K.T. 



Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify

items.label: Instruments Of Discipline
items.description:
Instruments Of DisciplineSchacke - Apocalyptic Decadence
Martin Schacke—of "Kisloty People" fame—has a knack for writing a hook. And almost every track of his debut album is decadent and addictive, loaded with catchy melodies. While the first half of the release gestures towards new beat and EBM—"Miasma Of Filth" and "Tasteless Passion" both pull from a lineage of tinny 808s and mid-tempo industrial—the second half offers grade-A techno-pop made for the the dance floor. Songs like "Body Type" and "Dungeon Crawler" are deceptively simple production-wise, but their repetitive choruses are the stuff that makes crossover hits. It's easy to imagine waiting for the train in the early morning hours after the rave, deliriously looping these brash three-note motifs again and again through your head.  -Chloe Lula



Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Ron Trent presents WARM - What Do The Stars Say To You
items.label: Night Time Stories
items.description:
Night Time StoriesRon Trent presents WARM - What Do The Stars Say To You
Ron Trent's WARM project captures it all in the name. As the Chicago house genius has advanced in his career, he's slowly luxuriated into a silky fusion sound that plucks from jazz, Balearic and soft rock in the spirit of carefully considered collaborators, like Texan psych-rock trio Khruangbin or Italian ambient composer Gigi Masin. "Admira," for instance, unfurls alongside loose bongo drums like a satisfying slow yawn after a midday slumber. Dappled sunlight patchworks "Flos Potentia," bound together by strumming bass guitar, and "On My Way Home," an earnest, jazzy sonic panacea for the oft-jaded ennui of modern music. After a long 11 years away from the format, Trent's latest album is a gorgeous evolution to behold. -W.W.



Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.text: Jamal Moss - Thanks 4 The Tracks U Lost
items.label: Modern Love
items.description:
Modern LoveJamal Moss - Thanks 4 The Tracks U Lost
Jamal Moss, under his own name and as Hieroglyphic Being, is one of the defining forces in Chicago dance music. Whether he's making jacking house, experimental noise or blown-out techno, his work is defined by its sense of pure energy as he whips his machines into a frenzy. You'll find plenty of that rawness on his first LP for Modern Love, but where Thanks 4 The Tracks U Lost stands apart is in its surprising tenderness. Don't get me wrong—the drums have plenty of edge, and Moss still pushes his synthesizers to their breaking points—but the record is strikingly wistful, making for one of the most beautiful and tenderhearted of the many albums he's released. -H.I.



Listen:
Apple Music / Spotify  / Soundcloud

items.label: Ratskin Records
items.description:
Ratskin RecordsBeast Nest - Sicko
In their work as an organiser and mediator, Beast Nest, AKA Sharmi Basu, believes that healing should be a communal effort. The process for making Sicko could be described as a collective effort. The LP was recorded in the years following 2016's tragic Ghost Ship fire, which ended up killing 36 people in an unlicensed warehouse. Sicko was an integral part of their healing journey as a survivor. There's palpable catharsis written into the energetic pulse of the album, which bleeds several genres into a satisfyingly cohesive mix that makes it difficult to discern where one song ends and another begins. Ambient sequences with knotty sections that twinkle and flutter turn into spaced out dub and then, somewhere along the way, listeners are transported to post-punk-leaning IDM. The songs sprawl out slowly, but capped at six tracks, the LP is actually quite short, emblematic of the slowness of grief and the unpredictable, dynamic moments that accompany it. -K.M.



Listen:
Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

items.text: Sudan Archives - Natural Brown Prom Queen
items.label: Stones Throw
items.description:
Stones ThrowSudan Archives - Natural Brown Prom Queen
Sudan Archives has always been a jewel of eccentricity. On her boundless second album, Natural Brown Prom Queen, rewind-worthy lyrics, maximalist experimentation (and what might be the most beat switches per song this year) coalesce into one remarkable document of self-empowerment and discovery.
